{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} '''''Jueves negro''''' (English: "Black Thursday") refers to a violent series of political demonstrations that created havoc in [[Guatemala City]] on 24 and 25 July 2003.
In May 2003, the [[Guatemalan Republican Front]] (FRG) political party selected former [[military dictatorship|military dictator]] [[Efraín Ríos Montt]] as its candidate for the forthcoming [[Guatemala election, 2003|November general election]]. However, his candidacy was initially rejected by the electoral registry and by two lower courts, on the grounds of a constitutional ban preventing former [[coup d'état|coup]] leaders from seeking the presidency (Ríos Montt had originally come to power by means of a coup d'état on 23 March 1982). On 14 July 2003, the [[Constitutional Court of Guatemala|Constitutional Court]], which had had several judges appointed from the FRG, approved his candidacy for president, arguing that the terms of the 1985 Constitution could not be applied [[Ex post facto law|retroactively]].
On 20 July, however, the [[Supreme Court of Guatemala|Supreme Court]] suspended his campaign for the presidency and agreed to hear a complaint brought by two right-of-centre parties that the general was constitutionally barred from running for president of the country. Ríos Montt denounced the ruling as judicial manipulation and, in a radio address, called on his followers to take to the streets to protest against this decision. On 24 July, the day known as '''jueves negro','' thousands of masked FRG supporters invaded the streets of Guatemala City, armed with machetes, clubs and guns. They had been bussed in from all over the country by the FRG amidst claims that people working in FRG-controlled municipalities were being blackmailed with being sacked if they did not attend the demonstration. The demonstrators blocked traffic, chanted threatening slogans, and waved their machetes about.
They were led by well known FRG militants, including a well known member of [[Congress of Guatemala|Congress]], who was photographed by the press early in the morning while co-ordinating the actions, and the secretary of Ríos Montt's daughter, [[Zury Ríos Montt|Zury]]. The demonstrators marched on the courts, the opposition parties headquarters, and newspapers, torching buildings, shooting out windows and burning cars and tyres in the streets. A TV journalist, [[Héctor Fernando Ramírez|Héctor Ramírez]], intervened to try and save a colleague who was being attacked by the demonstrators and died of a heart attack while running away from the mob. The situation was so chaotic over the weekend that both the UN mission and the U.S. embassy were closed.
Following the rioting, the Constitutional Court, packed with allies of Ríos Montt and his protégé, President [[Alfonso Portillo]], overturned the Supreme Court decision, upholding Ríos Montt's claim that the ban on coup leaders, formalized in the [[Constitution of Guatemala|1985 Constitution]], could not be applied retroactively to acts before that date. Many Guatemalans expressed anger over the Court's decision.
==Aftermath== Gen. Ríos Montt went on to be placed third in the November presidential vote, behind [[Álvaro Colom]] and [[Óscar Berger]].
Criminal charges were brought against seven FRG members for their role in inciting the riot and the manslaughter of Ramírez: Gen. Ríos Montt himself; Ingrid Elaine Argueta Sosa, his niece; Waleska Sánchez Velásquez, the secretary of Zury Ríos Montt; Jorge Arévalo, a congressional deputy; and Raúl Manchamé Leiva, a former director of the national police. [https://archive.is/20070710004304/http://www.prensalibre.com/pl/2004/marzo/06/83033.html] All were placed under house arrest. The charges against Gen. Ríos Montt were dismissed in January 2006.
In a related case, Carlos Ríos and four other members of the FRG were sentenced to three-year prison terms for racial discrimination (Guatemala's first such prosecution) for having levelled ethnic slurs at [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner [[Rigoberta Menchú]] during a later challenge lodged with the Constitutional Court. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4411207.stm] By paying stiffer fines in accordance with Guatemalan law, however, the five were able to escape serving jail time.
==Narrative of events (BBC News coverage)== *25 May 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/2934216.stm Guatemala coup leader to stand] (elected by party delegates) *8 June 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/2972468.stm Guatemala coup leader defies ban] (registration rejected by electoral authorities) *6 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3048612.stm Election setback for Guatemala general] (Supreme Court rejects appeal, upholds June ruling by Supreme Electoral Tribunal) *15 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3066855.stm Guatemala general can seek office] (Constitutional Court allows him to run, ruling that the Constitution can't be applied retroactively) *21 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3082675.stm Guatemala general blocked again] (suspension by the Supreme Court, following appeal lodged by opposition parties) *24 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3091843.stm Bar on Guatemala general upheld] (Constitutional Court upholds Supreme Court's suspension) *25 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3094857.stm Guatemala City hit by riot] (Black Thursday) *31 July 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3112047.stm General to run in Guatemala] (Constitutional Court overturns earlier ban) *11 November 2003: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3261329.stm Guatemala general 'accepts loss'] (Ríos Montt places third in first-round ballot) *9 March 2005 [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4332925.stm Guatemala Maya racism trial opens] (Guatemala's first race discrimination trial) * 5 April 2005 [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4411207.stm Guatemala politicians were racist] (five Guatemalan politicians have been found guilty of racial discrimination)
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060707144306/http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=4370 Political Violence in Guatemala] ([[ZNet]]) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060709143830/http://www.nisgua.org/articles/act_now_stop_frg_violence.htm Jueves negro action alert] ([[NISGUA]]) *[https://archive.is/20070927192440/http://www.prensalibre.com/pl/2003/julio/27/lectura_nac.html Diputados y funcionarios del partido oficial involucrados en ataque de turbas a la capital] (''[[Prensa Libre]]'' report from 27 July 2003)

The '''Kazan phenomenon''' ({{lang-ru|Казанский феномен}}) was a term used by journalists to describe the rise in street gang activity in the city of [[Kazan]] in the [[RSFSR]] and later, the [[Russian Federation]].
From the early 1970s, Kazan had a particularly bad reputation for [[juvenile delinquency]], and a substantial portion of young males in the area of both [[Russian people|Russian]] and [[Tatar]] background joined youth gangs, which fought amongst each other for territory, principally using improvised or [[melee weapon]]s (firearms are not widespread in Russia and are hard to come by). The crime wave caused a [[moral panic]] amongst the Soviet population, as not only was such criminality traditionally seen as a product of the capitalist West, but it also involved the children of local officials.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/world/kazan-journal-street-gangs-return-and-soviet-city-is-chagrined.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm NY Times – Kazan Journal; Street Gangs Return, and Soviet City Is Chagrined]</ref>
During the rise of the [[Russian mafia]] in the late 1980s and 1990s, the street gangs grew into more sophisticated and organised criminal enterprises. Due to the lack of profitability in running [[protection rackets]] in [[Tatarstan]], the Kazan gangs started to move to [[St Petersburg]], where they got into conflict with the local [[Tambov gang]]. The Kazan mafia was known to be particularly cruel in their extortion tactics, and periodically brought in reinforcements from Tatarstan. The Slavic gangsters of the city banded together to fight this emerging threat, and eventually forced the Tatars out of St Petersburg.<ref>Volkov, Vadim; Violent Entrepreneurs; 2002</ref>

{{Disability sidebar}}
A '''disability-rights activist''' or disability-rights advocate is someone who works towards the equality of people with [[disabilities]]. Such a person is generally considered a member of the [[disability rights movement|disability-rights movement]] and/or the [[Independent Living|independent-living movement]]. {{compact ToC|side=no|top=yes|num=no|seealso=no|extlinks=no|refs=yes}}
==A== * [[Javed Abidi]]{{spaced ndash}}Director of the [[National Centre for Promotion of Employment for Disabled People]] (NCPEDP) in [[India]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Demand-made-for-legal-recognition-of-sign-language/Article1-634161.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130126011941/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Demand-made-for-legal-recognition-of-sign-language/Article1-634161.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-26 |title=Demand made for legal recognition of sign language |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2010-12-04 |accessdate=2013-02-25 }}</ref> * [[Fatima al-Aqel]]{{spaced ndash}}opened a school for [[Visual impairment|blind]] women in [[Yemen]] in 1995.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url = http://yemen.usembassy.gov/iwds.html|title = Speech in Honor of International Women's Day|date = 8 March 2010|accessdate = 6 August 2015|website = Embassy of the United States - Yemen|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405221742/http://yemen.usembassy.gov/iwds.html|archivedate = 5 April 2015|df = }}</ref> * [[Ola Abu Alghaib]] – disability activist from Palestine, focusses on inclusion, gender and disability rights.
==B== * [[Jamala al-Baidhani]]{{spaced ndash}}created the Al-Tahadi Association for Disabled Females, the first group in [[Yemen]] devoted to helping girls with disabilities.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://yemen.usembassy.gov/iwds.html|title = Speech in Honor of International Women's Day|date = 8 March 2010|accessdate = 4 August 2015|website = Embassy of the United States in Sana'a Yemen|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405221742/http://yemen.usembassy.gov/iwds.html|archivedate = 5 April 2015|df = }}</ref> * [[Andrew Batavia]]{{spaced ndash}} ADA regulations drafter, co-founder AUTONOMY, Inc.<ref>DeJong Gerben Obituary: Andrew I Batavia The Lancet November 1, 2003, 1505</ref><ref>US Department of Justice Dick Thornburgh Papers http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/thornburgh/dtVideoPlayer?id=dtv182 The Americans with Disability Act Program 26 July 1991</ref><ref>Goodman Kenneth The Case of Terri Schiavo: Ethics, Politics, and Death in the 21st Century Oxford University Press, 2010, p 181 </ref> * [[Tiffany Brar]] founder of [[Jyothirgamaya Foundation]], a not for profit NGO for visually impaired * [[Gabriela Brimmer]]{{spaced ndash}}had [[cerebral palsy]]; life chronicled in the American-Mexican [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] ''[[Gaby: A True Story]]'' (1987), directed by [[Luis Mandoki]]<ref>{{cite news|author=Janet Maslin |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE2DA1F38F933A05753C1A961948260 |title=Film: 'Gaby,' Story of Determination |publisher=New York Times |date=1987-10-30 |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> * [[Marca Bristo]]{{spaced ndash}}cofounded the (American) National Council on Independent Living (NCIL) with [[Max Starkloff]] and Charlie Carr * [[Lydia Brown]]{{spaced ndash}} autism advocate and writer
==C== * [[Jane Campbell, Baroness Campbell of Surbiton]]{{spaced ndash}}commissioner of the British [[Disability Rights Commission]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2009/jul/11/lady-campbell-disability-peer|title=Dea Birkett meets Jane Campbell, a life peer with spinal muscular atrophy | Society|date=2009-07-10|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|author=Dea Birkett|accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> * [[Charlie Carr (activist)|Charlie Carr]]{{spaced ndash}}cofounder of National Council on Independent Living, Boston Center for Independent Living and founder and CEO of The Northeast Independent Living Program in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]]. Went on to become Commissioner of the Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission under Gov. [[Deval Patrick]].<ref name="Charles Carr">{{cite web|last1=Carr|first1=Charles|url=http://bancroft.berkeley.edu/collections/drilm/collection/items/carr.html|website=The Disability Rights And Independent Living Movement|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> * [[Liz Carr]] – [[United Kingdom|British]] [[actress]], [[stand-up comedian]], [[Television presenter|broadcaster]] and international [[disability rights activist]] * [[Judi Chamberlin]]{{spaced ndash}}American activist, leader, organizer, public speaker and educator in the [[psychiatric survivors movement]]; her political activism followed her involuntary confinement in a [[Psychiatric hospital|psychiatric facility]] in the 1960s<ref name=Hev>{{cite news|last=Hevesi, Denis|title=Judi Chamberlin, 65, Advocate for Mental Health Patients|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/31/us/31chamberlin.html|accessdate= March 1, 2011|work = [[The New York Times]] |date=January 30, 2010}}</ref><ref name=MR>{{cite web| publisher=Madness Radio|title=Interview: Judi Chamberlin Interviewed by Will Hall and Cheryl Alexander|url=http://www.madnessradio.net/madness-radio-judi-chamberlin-psychiatric-survivor-movement|accessdate= March 3, 2011|format= video; requires [[Adobe Flash Player]]|date=February 8, 2006}}</ref> the author of ''On Our Own: Patient-Controlled Alternatives to the Mental Health System,'' which is a foundational text in the [[Mad Pride]] movement<ref name=TBG>{{cite news|last=Lawrence|first=J.M.|title=Judi Chamberlin, Writings Took on Mental Health Care|url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/arlington/articles/2010/01/20/judi_chamberlin_writings_took_on_mental_health_care/?page=full|accessdate=March 4, 2011|work = [[The Boston Globe]]|date= January 20, 2010}}</ref> * [[James Charlton (activist)|James I. Charlton]]{{spaced ndash}}activist and author of [[Nothing About Us Without Us]] * [[Claudia Cockburn]]{{spaced ndash}}British activist for transportation accessibility<ref>{{cite news|author=Stephen Bradshaw |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-claudia-flanders-1173922.html |title=Obituary: Claudia Flanders - Arts & Entertainment |publisher=The Independent |date=1998-08-25 |accessdate=2013-02-25 |location=London}}</ref> * [[Tony Coelho]]{{spaced ndash}}former congressman from California, primary author and U.S. House sponsor of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.improvepatientcare.org/meet-tony-coelho |title=Meet Tony Coelho | Partnership to Improve Patient Care |publisher=Improvepatientcare.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> * [[Rebecca Cokley]]{{spaced ndash}}Executive Director of the [[National Council on Disability]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ncd.gov/newsroom/2013/041613|title=NCD Welcomes Rebecca Cokley as Executive Director {{!}} NCD.gov|website=www.ncd.gov|access-date=2016-05-28}}</ref> * [[Kitty Cone]]{{spaced ndash}}disability rights activist and staff member of the [[Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund]]
==D== * [[Justin Whitlock Dart, Jr.]]{{spaced ndash}}co-founder of the [[American Association of People with Disabilities]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Switzer|first=Jacqueline Vaughn|title=Disabled rights : American disability policy and the fight for equality|year=2003|publisher=Georgetown University Press|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=978-0878408986}}</ref> * [[Nyle DiMarco]]{{spaced ndash}}activist and spokesperson for LEAD-K, 'Language Equality and Acquisition for Deaf Kids' campaign for American Sign Language and English in education setting. * [[Rich Donovan]]{{spaced ndash}}economist and founder of the Return On Disability Index * [[Theresa Ducharme]]{{spaced ndash}}founder of the disabled-rights advocacy group [[People in Equal Participation Inc.]] in 1981; the organization's chair for many years thereafter<ref>"Disabled Want Their Say at Appeal", ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]''. January 3, 1995.</ref>
==E== * [[Dominick Evans]]{{spaced ndash}}filmmaker, activist, founder of #FilmDis. Media & Entertainment advocate for [[Center for Disability Rights]] in New York.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.self.com/trending/2016/05/why-some-disability-rights-activists-are-protesting-me-before-you/|title=Why Some Disability Rights Activists Are Protesting ‘Me Before You’ - SELF|website=SELF|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-28}}</ref> * [[Edward Evans (politician)|Edward Evans]]{{spaced ndash}}Chairman of the UK [[Ministry of Health Health Advisory Committee on Handicapped Persons]] from 1949 to 1960<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's who of British Members of Parliament.|year=1981|publisher=Harvester|location=[S.l.]|isbn=0-85527-335-6|page=111|last=Lees|first=Stephen|editor-last=Stenton|editor-first=Michael}}</ref>
==F== * [[Fred Fay]]{{spaced ndash}}American advocate for disabled persons.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-09-09/bostonglobe/30136052_1_americans-with-disabilities-act-concord-home-spinal-cord |title=Dr. Fred Fay; helped change society’s views on disability - The Boston Globe |publisher=Articles.boston.com |date=2011-09-09 |accessdate=2013-02-25 |first=Bryan |last=Marquard |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516082149/http://articles.boston.com/2011-09-09/bostonglobe/30136052_1_americans-with-disabilities-act-concord-home-spinal-cord |archivedate=2012-05-16 |df= }}</ref> * [[Julie Fernandez]]{{spaced ndash}}actress with [[osteogenesis imperfecta]]; founded [[The Disability Foundation]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tdf.org.uk/about/julie-fernandez.htm |title=Founder Julie Fernandez | The Disability Foundation |publisher=Tdf.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523183551/http://www.tdf.org.uk/about/julie-fernandez.htm |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }}</ref> active on presentation of the disabled.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rozenberg |first=Joshua |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1471307/Land-of-the-free-for-wheelchairs.html |title=Land of the free for wheelchairs |publisher=Telegraph |date=2004-09-09 |accessdate=2013-02-25 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Geoff Adams-Spink |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4490063.stm |title=UK | Disabled feel 'sexually excluded' |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-04-28 |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> * [[Catherine Frazee]]{{spaced ndash}}co-director of [[Ryerson University]]'s [[Institute for Disability Studies Research and Education]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnw.ca/fr/releases/archive/October2007/04/c8571.html |title=Ryerson University | Employees with disabilities are expert learners: Ryerson study |publisher=Cnw.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> * [[Lex Frieden]]{{spaced ndash}}Chairman of the [[National Council on Disability]] from 2002-2006; '''Madeleine Pelner Cosman''' (December 4, 1937 – March 2, 2006) was a scholar, a policy analyst, an advocate, a prolific author, and a faculty member at [[City College of New York]]. "As a medical lawyer, educator and health-care policy guru, she testified before Congress, wrote 15 books and buttressed conservative politicians' arguments against immigration""She was recruited by all these politicians to present ideas with coherence, logic and dramatic flair," her daughter said. "But before the political world took notice, the intellectual world was pretty much aware of her." Lecture appointments took Cosman throughout the United States and to Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Israel, and Western Europe. She also contributed to think tanks that reflected her philosophy on medical and legal issues, the [[Cato Institute]] and [[Galen Institute]]. Cosman died in Escondido, Calif. She was 68. The cause was complications of [[scleroderma]], a chronic disease of the connective tissue, her family said.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/19/nyregion/19cosman.html|title=Madeleine P. Cosman, 68, Medieval Expert, Dies|date=March 19, 2006| author=Margalit Fox|newspaper=New York Times}} ==Education== Cosman's degrees include[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/19/nyregion/19cosman.html?ex=1300424400&en=75a1df0598ca0de5&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss Margalit Fox, "Madeleine P. Cosman, 68, Medieval Expert, Dies," ''New York Times'', 19 March 2006, accessed 4 Dec 2007]{{cite web|url=http://www.fullcontext.info/people/cosman.htm|title=Madeleine Pelner Cosman|work=Full Context|date=December 1997}} *[[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from the [[Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law]] (1995) *[[Ph.D.]] in English and [[comparative literature]] from [[Columbia University]] (1964) *[[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in Comparative Literature from [[Hunter College]] (1960) *[[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] from [[Barnard College]] (1959) Cosman was a professor in the Department of English at [[City College of New York]] from 1964 until her retirement in 1993. She was a member of the [[New York Academy of Medicine]] and a Professor of Medical Law.{{cite web|url=http://www.nyam.org/library/rare-book-room/newsletter-archives/rb_newsletter_malloch4.pdf|title=The New York Academy of Medicine Special Collections, Malloch Room Newsletter|publisher=The New York Academy of Medicine}} ==Renaissance Studies== In 1968, Cosman became founding director of the [[City College of New York]] Institute for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, which granted undergraduate and graduate degrees. From the 1970s she helped organize the Renaissance Fair at [[The Cloisters]]. She was also a scholar of medieval medicine. Her book, ''Fabulous Feasts: Medieval Cookery and Ceremony'' (1976) was nominated for a [[Pulitzer Prize]] and the [[National Book Award]]. According to one obituary, she lectured for years "on cable television at the Metropolitan Museum of New York on medieval daily life. She was deeply passionate about ideas and her gift was to share her ideas with an intelligent audience." ==Advocacy== "She never practised law," her daughter said. "She used her knowledge of the law to be more effective as a policy analyst."{{cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/obituaries/20060311-9999-1m11cosman.html|title=Madeleine Cosman, 68; medical lawyer, author|date=March 11, 2006|author=Jack Williams|newspaper=Union-Tribune}} "Known for an engaging speaking style that illuminated her legal savvy, Cosman was a favorite guest on talk radio." She was a board member of the California Rifle and Pistol Association. ===Health-care policy=== For nearly 30 years, Cosman taught medical students [[medical law]], [[medical business]] and [[medical history]] at City College of City University of New York. and was a strong advocate for personal choice of one's own medical care. Her views spawned an hourlong presentation on C-span titled "Who owns your body" as well as books titled "ABCs of the Clinton Medical World" (published 1993) and "Selling the Medical Practice: The Physicians and Surgeons Guide" (published 1988) ===Immigration issues=== Cosman appeared frequently with host Mark Edwards of "Wake Up America" and provided the medical legal data for "Hold Their Feet to the Fire," a project of [[Americans for Legal Immigration - ALIPAC]].[http://www.holdtheirfeettothefire.org/ Hold Their Feet to the Fire / Amnesty Alamo. Washington D.C. April 21-25, 2007. NO AMNESTY FOR ILLEGALS!] One article she wrote for the ''[[Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons]]'' titled "Illegal Aliens and American Medicine" [http://www.jpands.org/vol10no1/cosman.pdf Madeline Cosman, "Illegal Aliens and American Medicine", ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'', Spring 2005, accessed 4 Dec 2007] stated:
"Horrendous diseases that long ago America had conquered are resurging," she wrote last April. "Horrific diseases common in Third World poverty and medical ignorance suddenly are appearing in American emergency rooms and medical offices."
Also, she argued that 80 California hospitals closed between 1994 and 2003 because of the [[Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act]] requirement that those hospitals provide services (including childbirth) to illegal aliens in the emergency room regardless of their ability to pay. ==Criticism== {{See also|Association of American Physicians and Surgeons#Leprosy error}} Critics have objected that many of her controversial claims on immigration and medicine are not authoritative due her lack of credentials.e.g., Amy Goodman and Lou Dobbs in ''DemocracyNow!'' transcript cited below. A reporter on [[Lou Dobbs]]' [[Lou Dobbs Tonight|CNN program]]{{cite news | url = http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0705/07/ldt.01.html | title = Lou Dobbs Tonight transcripts | date = 2007-05-07 | work = [[CNN]] | accessdate = 2007-12-05 }} had cited as facts Cosman's claims that there were over a period of three years 7000 cases of [[leprosy]] in the United States and that many of them were the result of illegal immigrants bringing the disease into the country when the statistics show the number was for a 30-year period and unrelated to immigration. Dobbs has since rejected the claims as unsubstantiated.[http://www.democracynow.org/2007/12/4/fact_checking_dobbs_cnn_anchor_lou Transcript of ''DemocracyNow!'' broadcast, 4 Dec 2007, accessed 4 Dec 2007] Cosman has also been accused[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/30/business/30leonhardt.html?pagewanted=all [[David Leonhardt]], "Truth, Fiction and Lou Dobbs", ''New York Times'', 30 May 2007]; [http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/05/29/Dobbs.May30/index.html Lou Dobbs, "An answer for my critics", ''cnn.com'', 31 May 2007]; [[Gustavo Arellano]], "[[¡Ask a Mexican!]]" column in [http://www.ocweekly.com/columns/ask-a-mexican/ask-a-mexican/28061/ 15 Nov 2007 issue] of ''[[OC Weekly]]'' online; all accessed 9 Dec 2007. of anti-Mexican bias. For example, railing against criminals from the immigrant community, she made the following ominous warning: "Recognize that most of these bastards molest girls under age twelve, some as young as age five, others age three. Although, of course, some specialize in boys, some specialize in nuns, some are exceedingly versatile and rape little girls age eleven and women up to age seventy-nine."[http://www.democracynow.org/2007/12/4/fact_checking_dobbs_cnn_anchor_lou Transcript of ''DemocracyNow!'' broadcast, 4 Dec 2007, accessed 8 Dec 2007]; see also a {{YouTube|pzdAmu_GffM|Version of the quote}}, accessed 8 Dec 2007. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cosman, Madeleine Pelner}} [[Category:Barnard College alumni]] [[Category:City College of New York faculty]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Medical law]] [[Category:American anti–illegal immigration activists]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American lawyers]]

{{Infobox person | name = Mary Beth Tinker | image = File:Mary Beth Tinker at Ithaca College, 19 September 2017.jpg | image_size = | caption = Mary Beth Tinker holding her original detention slip while wearing a replica of her black armband at [[Ithaca College]] in 2017 | birth_date = 1952 | birth_place = [[Des Moines, Iowa]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relatives = [[Love Makes a Family|Bonnie Tinker]] (sister) }}
'''Mary Beth Tinker''' is an American free speech activist known for her role in the 1969 ''[[Tinker v. Des Moines Independent School District]]'' Supreme Court case, which ruled that Warren Harding Junior High School could not punish her for wearing a black armband in school in support of a truce in the [[Vietnam War]]. The case set a precedent for student speech in schools.
== Tinker v. Des Moines == {{BLP refimprove|section|date=January 2018}} When Tinker was 13, she wore a black armband to school in protest of the United States' involvement in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] as a member of a group of students who decided to do this.<ref>Bonner, A. et al (1995) "From Tinker to Hazelwood: Landmark Supreme Court decisions and how schools deal with them", in ''Death By Cheeseburger: High School Journalism in the 1990s and Beyond.'' Washington, DC: The Freedom Forum.</ref>
On December 11, 1965, a student named Christopher Eckhardt held a meeting with a large group of students at his home in Des Moines, Iowa. Planning a school protest against the Vietnam War, the group decided to wear black armbands in school on December 16. They chose to keep wearing them until January 1, 1966. During a meeting for [[Des Moines School District]] principals on December 14, 1965, a policy was adopted that required all students wearing armbands in school to remove them. In this meeting, principals agreed that students were to be [[Suspension (punishment)#Academia|suspended]] if they disagreed.
Thirteen-year-old Mary Beth Tinker was a student at [[Harding Middle School|Warren Harding Junior High]] who was among two dozen elementary, middle, and high school students that wore black arm bands to school on December 16 and 17. Five students were singled out for punishment, including Mary Beth and her brother John.
Tinker reported that immediately after being suspended, her family received many threats from the public. "A man who had a radio talk show threatened my father on the air. Red paint was thrown on our house. A woman called on the phone, asked for me by name, and then said, 'I’m going to kill you!'"
On December 21, 200 people attended the district school board meeting. Deciding to postpone a decision, at a January 3 meeting, the school board voted 5-2 to uphold the principals' ban. On March 14, the [[American Civil Liberties Union|Iowa Civil Liberties Union]] filed a formal complaint on behalf of Christopher Eckhardt, John Tinker, his sister Mary Beth, and their fathers in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa|U. S. District Court of the Southern District of Iowa]]. The case claimed that by suspending them, Des Moines Public Schools had infringed on their right to free expression as enshrined in [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]. The District Court dismissed the complaint and upheld the constitutionality of the school actions, on the basis that the students disturbed learning in their schools.
After that, the justices for the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the 8th Circuit]] were split, leaving the District Court ruling standing. The case reached the Supreme Court on November 12, 1968. On February 24, 1969, the Supreme Court found that by suspending Tinker and her peers for wearing the armbands, Des Moines School District violated the students' First Amendment rights. The Supreme Court’s decision in Tinker is said to have set the legal standard for student free expression for many years.
== In Time == Today, Tinker conducts speaking tours across the United States to teach children and youth about their rights. A [[youth rights]] advocate, Tinker has a professional background as a pediatric nurse who is active in union activism and holds [[masters degree]]s in both [[public health]] and [[nursing]].<ref>[http://tinkertourusa.org/about/tinkerbio/ "Mary Beth Tinker Biography"], Tinker Tour USA. Retrieved September 15, 2013.</ref>
According to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', in fall 2013, Tinker began a national tour promoting [[youth activism]] and [[youth rights]] with student rights attorney Mike Hiestand known as the "Tinker Tour".<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/news/us/article/Plaintiff-in-iconic-school-speech-case-starts-tour-4815977.php "Plaintiff in iconic school speech case starts tour"], ''San Francisco Chronicle''. Retrieved September 15, 2013.</ref> During the fall of 2013, the pair traveled 15,595 miles across the American east coast, midwest and southeast speaking to more than 20,000 students and teachers at 58 stops, including schools, colleges, churches, a youth detention facility, courts and several national conventions. The tour was scheduled to visit schools and events in the American west, midwest and southwest during the spring of 2014.<ref>[http://tinkertourusa.org/about/tinkertour/ "About the Tinker Tour"], Tinker Tour USA. Retrieved February 11, 2014.</ref>
== Honors ==
In 2000, an annual youth advocacy award of the Marshall-Brennan Project at [[Washington College of Law|Washington College of Law at American University]] honored Tinker by naming the award after her.<ref>[http://www.wcl.american.edu/marshallbrennan/marytinker_award.cfm "Mary Beth Tinker Award"] Washington College of Law. Retrieved September 15, 2013.</ref> In 2006, the ACLU National Board of Directors’ Youth Affairs Committee renamed its annual youth affairs award the Mary Beth Tinker Youth Involvement Award.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/free-speech/tinker-v-des-moines-393-us-503-1969 "Tinker v. Des Moines (393 U.S. 503, 1969)"] American Civil Liberties Union. Retrieved September 15, 2013.</ref>

}} The '''Mro People''' ({{lang-my| [https://my.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E1%80%99%E1%80%BC%E1%80%AD%E1%80%AF%E1%80%9C%E1%80%B0%E1%80%99%E1%80%BB%E1%80%AD%E1%80%AF%E1%80%B8 မြိုလူမျိုး]}}) are one of the 135 ethnic groups recognized by the government of [[Myanmar]].They are identified as a sub-group of Chin people. Also known as '''Mro, Mro (Wakim), Awa Khami, Khami, Khumi Awa, Mro-Khimi, “Kwe Myi”''' in Myanmar.The live widely in some parts of northern Rakine state, Chin state, the townships of Matupi and Paletwa, and the regions of Samechaung and Michaung. They are Tibeto-Burman and have their own language, culture and customs which are still in existence.For Chin specifically, the Awa Khami are one of 53 sub-groups identified by the government of Myanmar.

== Religion ==
=== Animism === The Mro People still believe animism as their custome, especially for their traditional festival. Merely 36.60%.
=== Buddhism === The Mro practise both animism and Buddhism. A strong Buddhist influence exists as about 55% of the population adhering to Theravada Buddhism, a common sect of Buddhism eminent throughout mainland Southeast Asia, especially in Myanmar (Burma) and Thailand.
=== Christianity === Merely 7.14% of the Mro adheres to Christianity. New Testament was translated into Mro language in 2017.
==Language==
They primarily speak the Mro language, [[Kuki-Chin languages|Kuki-Chin language]] of [[Burma]], Mro is spoken in the following townships of Myanmar (''[[Ethnologue]]''). *[[Chin State]]: [[Paletwa]] township *[[Rakhine State]]: [[Kyauktaw]], [[Buthidaung]], [[Ponnagyun]], [[Pauktaw]], [[Mrauk U]], and [[Maungdaw]] townships.
There are 4 main dialects of Mro (''[[Ethnologue]]'').
* .Arang (Ahraing Khami, Areung, Aroeng) * .Xengna (Hrengna) * .Xata * .Vakung (Wakun, Wakung).
Arang (Ahraing Khami, Areung, Aroeng), Xengna (Hrengna), Xata, Vakung (Wakun, Wakung). Generally high comprehension of Vakung dialect among other dialect speakers. Wakun (Vakung) is the most widely spoken and understood dialect (Horney 2009:5) and basis of literature. Lexical similarity: 91%–98% within Mro(Khimi) varieties, 86%–90% with Likhy variety of Eastern Khumi [cek], 81%–85% with Lemi variety of Eastern Khumi [cek], 77%–81% with Kaladan Khumi [cnk].

Accessed 18 August 2017.]] The '''North Korean cult of personality''' surrounding its ruling family, the [[Kim dynasty (North Korea)|Kim family]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16336991 |title=Delving into North Korea's mystical cult of personality |author=Lucy Williamson |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=December 27, 2011 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202083328/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16336991 |archivedate=February 2, 2013 }} has existed in [[North Korea]] for decades and can be found in many examples of [[Culture of North Korea|North Korean culture]].Choe, Yong-ho., Lee, Peter H., and de Barry, Wm. Theodore., eds. ''Sources of Korean Tradition'', Chichester, NY: Columbia University Press, p. 419, 2000. Although not acknowledged by the [[government of North Korea|North Korean government]], many [[North Korean defectors|defectors]] and [[Tourism in North Korea|Western visitors]] state there are often stiff penalties for those who criticize or do not show "proper" respect for the regime.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2012/01/north-korea-reportedly-punishing-insincere-mourners/ |title=North Korea Reportedly Punishing Insincere Mourners |author=Ben Forer |publisher=''ABC News'' |date=January 12, 2012 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414203420/http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2012/01/north-korea-reportedly-punishing-insincere-mourners/ |archivedate=April 14, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=https://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/cis/cis_988.html#criminal_penalties |title=DPRK, Criminal Penalties |publisher=''US State Dept'' |date=December 2, 2011 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101184313/http://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/cis/cis_988.html |archivedate=January 1, 2013 }} The personality cult began soon after [[Kim Il-sung]] took power in 1948, and was greatly expanded after [[Death and state funeral of Kim Il-sung|his death]] in 1994. The cult is also marked by the intensity of the people's feelings for and devotion to their leaders,{{cite book|last=Hunter |first=Helen-Louise |title=Kim Il-song's North Korea |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lrz5OJvCkmIC&pg=PA25 |accessdate=August 31, 2013 |year=1999 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=9780275962968 |page=262 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111161606/http://books.google.com/books?id=lrz5OJvCkmIC&pg=PA25 |archivedate=January 11, 2014 }}{{rp|25}} and the key role played by a Confucianized ideology of [[familism]] both in maintaining the cult and thereby in sustaining the regime itself. The North Korean cult of personality is a large part of [[Juche|North Korean socialism]] and [[totalitarianism]]. ==Background== According to [[Dae-Sook Suh|Suh Dae-sook]], the cult of personality surrounding the Kim family requires total loyalty and subjugation to the Kim family and establishes the country as a one-man dictatorship through successive generations.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=314}} The [[Constitution of North Korea#1972 revision|1972 constitution]] of North Korea incorporates the ideas of Kim Il-sung as the only guiding principle of the state and his activities as the only cultural heritage of the people.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=315}} According to ''New Focus International'', the cult of personality, particularly surrounding Kim Il-sung, has been crucial for legitimizing the family's hereditary succession,{{cite web|url=http://newfocusintl.com/just-witnessed-coup-north-korea/ |title=We have just witnessed a coup in North Korea |author=Staff |publisher=New Focus International |date=December 27, 2013 |accessdate=January 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126131556/http://newfocusintl.com/just-witnessed-coup-north-korea/ |archivedate=January 26, 2014 }} and Park Yong-soo said in the ''[[Australian Journal of International Affairs]]'' that the "prestige of the Suryong [supreme leader] has been given the highest priority over everything else in North Korea".{{cite journal |last=Park |first=Yong-Soo |year=2009 |title=The political economy of economic reform in North Korea |journal=Australian Journal of International Affairs |volume=63 |issue=4 |page=542 |publisher=Australian Institute of International Affairs |format=PDF |doi=10.1080/10357710903312587 |id= |accessdate=January 22, 2014 19, 2014 |df= }} Kim Il-sung developed{{when|date=August 2017}} the political ideology of the ''[[Juche]]'' idea, generally understood as ''self-reliance'', and further developed it between the 1950s and the 1970s. ''Juche'' became the main guide of all forms of thought, education, culture and life throughout the nation{{cite book |last=Cumings |first=Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Cumings |title=Korea's Place in the Sun: a Modern History |year=2005 |publisher=W. W. Norton |location=United States of America |isbn=0393327027 |pages=414–446 }} until{{when|date=August 2017}} [[Kim Jong-il]] introduced the ''[[Songun]]'' (military-first) policy, which augments the ''Juche'' philosophy{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/dprk/juche.htm |title=Juche |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org |accessdate=January 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123060052/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/dprk/juche.htm |archivedate=January 23, 2013 }} and has a great impact on national economic policies. {{cite web|url=http://keia.org/publication/military-first-politics-songun-understanding-kim-jong-ils-north-korea |title=Military-First Politics (Songun) |page=6 |author=Han S Park 2017}}{{sfn|Alton|Chidley|2013|p=109}} {{cite web|url=http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/book/reading.php?12 |title=Let us brilliantly accomplish the revolutionary cause of Juche |author=Kim Jong-un |publisher=''Naenara'' |year=2012 |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115032451/http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/book/reading.php?12 |archivedate=January 15, 2013 }} According to a 2013 report by ''New Focus International'', the two major Korean news publications (''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'' and the [[Korean Central News Agency]]) publish around 300 articles per month relating to the "cult of Kim". {{cite web|url=http://newfocusintl.com/north-koreans-losing-interest-cult-of-kim/ |title=North Koreans Losing Interest In Cult Of Kim? |publisher=''New Focus International'' |date=May 20, 2013 |accessdate=May 24, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802230842/http://newfocusintl.com/north-koreans-losing-interest-cult-of-kim/ Retrieved 18 December 2007. ==Kim Il-sung== {{see also|List of things named after Kim Il-sung}} [[File:Image of Kim Il-sung.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Image shown during an [[Arirang Festival]].]] [[File:Pyongyang Mural.jpg|thumb|Pyongyang Mural|A mural of Kim Il-sung giving a speech in Pyongyang.]] The personality cult surrounding [[Kim Il-sung]] is by far the most widespread among the people.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8975559/The-stage-management-of-the-grief-for-Kim-Jong-il.html |title=The stage management of the grief for Kim Jong-il |author=Dean Nelson |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |date=December 23, 2011 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314011224/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8975559/The-stage-management-of-the-grief-for-Kim-Jong-il.html |archivedate=March 14, 2012 }} While there is genuine affection for Kim Il-sung, it has been manipulated by the government for political purposes.{{cite book|last=Portal |first=Jane |title=Art Under Control in North Korea |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_V3qAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA98 |accessdate=January 27, 2013 |year=2005 |publisher=Reaktion Books |location=United Kingdom |isbn=9781861898388 |page=98 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627025935/http://books.google.com/books?id=_V3qAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA98 |archivedate=June 27, 2014 }} The cult had its beginnings as early as 1949, with the appearance of the first statues of Kim Il-sung.{{cite book |title=Rogue Regime: Kim Jong Il and the Looming Threat of North Korea |last=Becker|first=Jasper |authorlink=Jasper Becker |year=2005 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-517044-3}} The veneration of Kim Il-sung came into full effect following a mass [[purge]] in 1953.{{cite web|url=http://world.kbs.co.kr/english/event/nkorea_nuclear/general_04a.htm |title=Kim Il-sung (1912~1994) |publisher=''KBS World Radio'' |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319020430/http://world.kbs.co.kr/english/event/nkorea_nuclear/general_04a.htm |archivedate=March 19, 2013 }} In 1967, Kim Jong-il was appointed to the state propaganda and information department, where he began to focus his energy on developing the veneration of his father.{{cite book |first=John |last=Cha |title=Exit Emperor Kim Jong-il |publisher=Abbott Press |location=United States |year=2012 |pages= |isbn=978-1-4582-0216-1}}{{rp|39}} It was around this time that the title ''Suryong'' (Great Leader or Supreme Leader) came into habitual usage.{{cite book |first=Jae-Cheon |last=Lim |title=Kim Jong-il's Leadership of North Korea |publisher=Routledge |location= |year=2008 |pages= |isbn=9780203884720}}{{rp|40}} However, Kim Il-sung had begun calling himself "Great Leader" as early as 1949. [[Hwang Jang-yop]], the highest level [[North Korean defector]], has said that the country is completely ruled by the sole ideology of the "[[Great Leader (concept)|Great Leader]]". He further said that during the [[De-Stalinization]] period in the [[USSR]], when [[Stalin's cult of personality]] was dismantled in 1956, some North Korean students studying in the Soviet Union also began to criticize Kim Il-sung's growing personality cult and when they returned home they "were subject to intensive interrogation that lasted for months" and "Those found the least bit suspicious were killed in secret".{{cite web|url=http://www2.law.columbia.edu/course_00S_L9436_001/North%20Korea%20materials/hwang%20jang3.html |title=The Problems of Human Rights in North Korea |author=Hwang Jang-yop |publisher=Columbia Law School |year=2006 |accessdate=January 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130104210611/http://www2.law.columbia.edu/course_00S_L9436_001/North%20Korea%20materials/hwang%20jang3.html |archivedate=January 4, 2013 }} According to official biographies, Kim Il-sung came from a long lineage of leaders and official North Korean modern history focuses on his life and activities. He is credited with almost single-handedly defeating the Japanese at the end of the [[Korea under Japanese rule|occupation of Korea]] (ignoring Soviet and American efforts){{cite book |first=Bruce |last=Cumings |title=Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History |publisher=W W Norton & Co |location=United States |year=1997 |page=160 |isbn=0-393-04011-9 }} and with rebuilding the nation after the [[Korean War]]. Over the course of his life he was granted titles of esteem such as "Sun", "Great Chairman", "Heavenly Leader" [[List of Kim Il-sung's titles|and many others]], as well as awards like the "Double Hero Gold Medal". These titles and awards were often self-given and the practice would be repeated by his son.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=320}} The Korean Central News Agency (the official government news agency) continually reported on the titles and perceived affection granted to Kim Il-sung by world leaders including [[Mao Zedong]] of China, [[Fidel Castro]] of Cuba and [[Jimmy Carter]] of the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201204/news03/20120403-27ee.html |title=Humankind Awards Many Titles to Kim Il Sung |publisher=''Korean Central News Agency'' |date=April 3, 2012 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201134244/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201204/news03/20120403-27ee.html |archivedate=February 1, 2014 }} [[File:Large-Kim-Paintings-2014.jpg|thumb|Large portraits on the wall of the [[Grand People's Study House]], facing Kim Il-sung Square in Pyongyang, North Korea.]] All major publications (newspapers, textbooks etc.) were to include "words of instruction" from Kim Il-sung. Additionally, his name must be written as a single word in one line, it may not be split into two parts if there is a page break or the line of text runs out of room (for example: Kim Il-sung, not Kim Il-...sung).{{cite web|url=http://newfocusintl.com/bewildering-cult-of-kim/?fb_source=pubv1 |title=The Bewildering Cult of Kim |publisher=New Focus International |date=May 27, 2013 |accessdate=May 27, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407074839/http://newfocusintl.com/bewildering-cult-of-kim/?fb_source=pubv1 |archivedate=April 7, 2014 }} North Korean children were taught in school that they were fed, clothed and nurtured in all aspects by the "grace of the Chairman". The larger elementary schools in the country have a room set aside for lectures that deal specifically with Kim Il-sung (known as the Kim Il-sung Research Institute). These rooms are well taken care of, are built of high quality materials, and have a model of his birthplace in [[Mangyongdae-guyok]].{{harvnb|Demick|2009|pp=120–123}} The size of the images of him which adorned public buildings are regulated to be in proportion to the size of the building on which they hang.{{cite web|url=http://nothingtoenvy.com/nothing-to-envy-excerpt/ |title=Nothing to Envy Excerpt |first=Barbara |last=Demick |publisher=Nothingtoenvy.com |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105210450/http://nothingtoenvy.com/nothing-to-envy-excerpt/ |archivedate=November 5, 2012 }} His place of birth has also become a place of pilgrimage. [[Kang Chol-hwan]] wrote of his childhood in North Korea:
To my childish eyes and to those of all my friends, Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il were perfect beings, untarnished by any base human function. I was convinced, as we all were, that neither of them urinated or defecated. Who could imagine such things of gods?Chol-hwan Kang and Pierre Rigoulot (2005). ''The Aquariums of Pyongyang: Ten Years in the North Korean Gulag'', Basic Books, p. 3. {{ISBN|0-465-01104-7}}.
In his memoir, Kim Il-sung tells an anecdote involving his father and grandfather that gives the rationale for this sanitized presentation of North Korean leaders to their followers. The memoir says that as a young pupil, Kim Il-sung's father was often sent to fetch wine for one of his teachers, who drank frequently, until one day his father saw the drunken teacher fall face-first into a ditch. This led to a confrontation in which the young pupil shamed the embarrassed teacher into giving up wine altogether. Kim Il-sung's grandfather draws the moral of this story:
My grandfather's opinion was this: If pupils peep into their teacher's private life frequently, they lose their awe of him; the teacher must give his pupils the firm belief that their teacher neither eats nor urinates; only then can he maintain his authority at school; so a teacher should set up a screen and live behind it.With the Century, Kim Il-sung, 1992, Chapter 3.2. {{cite web |url=http://ndfsk.dyndns.org/kuguk8/rem/rem-1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140828045348/http://ndfsk.dyndns.org/kuguk8/rem/rem-1.htm |archivedate=2014-08-28 |df= }} accessed 27 August 2014. Note that the version of With the Century available at the official North Korean Government web site (https://web.archive.org/web/20051231095503/http://www.korea-dpr.com/articles-ng/biography-kimilsung.htm) includes the anecdote and the grandfather's moral, but omits the detail about the necessity of screening eating/urinating from pupils.
Biographer Dae-Sook Suh notes:
The magnitude of adulation often borders on fanaticism. His photograph is displayed ahead of the national flag and national emblem; the song of Marshal Kim Il-sung is played ahead of the national anthem; the best institution of higher learning is named after him; the highest party school is also named after him; and there are songs, poems, essays, stories, and even a flower named after him.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=316}}
The [[Kimilsungia]] is an orchid named after Kim Il-sung by Indonesian former president [[Sukarno]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2131577/North-Koreans-celebrate-100th-anniversary-founding-father-Kim-Il-Sungs-birth.html |title=Here's us with the Kims: North Koreans flock in their thousands to celebrate 100th anniversary of founding father's birth... with a happy snap in front of massive portrait |author=Jill Reilly |publisher=Daily Mail |date=April 18, 2012 |accessdate=July 25, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130726040002/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2131577/North-Koreans-celebrate-100th-anniversary-founding-father-Kim-Il-Sungs-birth.html |archivedate=July 26, 2013 }} It was named after him in 1965 during a visit to the [[Bogor Botanical Garden]]s. According to a 2005 speech by Kim Jong-il, Sukarno and the garden's director wanted to name the flower after Kim Il-sung. Kim Il-sung declined, yet Sukarno insisted, "No. You have rendered enormous services to mankind, so you deserve a high honour."{{cite web|url=http://photoblog.nbcnews.com/_news/2011/04/06/6417291-flowers-and-north-korea?lite |title=Flowers and North Korea |author=David R Arnott |publisher=NBC News |date=April 6, 2011 |accessdate=July 25, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526083536/http://photoblog.nbcnews.com/_news/2011/04/06/6417291-flowers-and-north-korea?lite |archivedate=May 26, 2013 }} Domestically, the flowers (and the [[Kimjongilia]], described below) are used in idolizing the leadership.{{cite book |last=Angélil |first=Marc |last2=Hehl |first2=Rainer |title=Collectivize: Essays on the Political Economy of Territory, Vol. 2 |year=2013 |publisher=Ruby Press |location=Berlin |isbn=978-3-944074-03-0 |page=99}} When Kim Il-sung died in 1994, Kim Jong-il declared a national mourning period for three years.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57346034/kim-jong-il-publicly-mourned-by-thousands/ |title=Kim Jong Il publicly mourned by thousandsg |publisher=CBS News |date=December 21, 2011 |accessdate=August 31, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019141409/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57346034/kim-jong-il-publicly-mourned-by-thousands/ |archivedate=October 19, 2013 }} Those who were found violating the mourning rules (such as drinking) were met with punishment.{{harvnb|Martin|2006|p=508}} After his death he was referred to as the "[[Eternal President]]". In 1998 the [[Constitution of North Korea|national constitution]] was changed to reflect this.[[s:Constitution of North Korea (1972)|Constitution of North Korea (1988 amended)]] Wikisource When his father died, Kim Jong-il greatly expanded the nation's cult of personality.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/kim-jongil-leader-of-north-korea-who-deepened-the-cult-of-personality-in-his-country-following-the-death-of-his-father-6279399.html |title=Kim Jong-Il: Leader of North Korea who deepened the cult of personality in his country following the death of his father |author=David McNeill |publisher=The Independent |date=December 20, 2011 |accessdate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214172856/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/kim-jongil-leader-of-north-korea-who-deepened-the-cult-of-personality-in-his-country-following-the-death-of-his-father-6279399.html |archivedate=December 14, 2013 }} In 1997, the [[North Korean calendar|Juche Era dating system]], which begins with the birth of Kim Il-sung (April 15, 1912) as year 1, was introduced and replaced the [[Gregorian calendar]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2012/04/2012410111258757121.html |title=North Korea celebrates 'Juche 101' |author=Ben Piven |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=April 10, 2012 |accessdate=August 22, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523235040/http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2012/04/2012410111258757121.html |archivedate=May 23, 2013 }}{{cite book|first=Hy-Sang |last=Lee |title=North Korea: A Strange Socialist Fortress |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6Rx8Q_cxqvkC&pg=PA220 |accessdate=August 22, 2013 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2001 |page=220 |isbn=9780275969172 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111115031/http://books.google.com/books?id=6Rx8Q_cxqvkC&pg=PA220 |archivedate=January 11, 2014 }} The year {{CURRENTYEAR}} would thus correspond to Juche {{Years ago|1911}} (there is no year 0). July 8, 2014 marked the 20th anniversary of Kim Il-sung's death. North Korean authorities declared a ten-day mourning period which ran from July 1 to July 10.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?num=12042&cataId=nk01500 |title=Kim's Death Sees Songs and Ten Days of Mourning |author=Kang Mi Jin |publisher=DailyNK |date=July 5, 2014 |accessdate=July 5, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707143136/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?num=12042&cataId=nk01500 |archivedate=July 7, 2014 }} The anniversary involved lectures, study sessions, local choirs, etc., with children and workers being mobilized to take part in the various events. According to a resident of [[Hyesan]], "Nowadays people are having a hard time... as events related to the passing of the Suryeong are going on every single day in the Democratic Women's Union and workplaces alike". Nevertheless, the resident said, "Nobody is complaining about it, maybe because ever since the purge of [[Jang Song-thaek|Jang Song-taek]] last year, if you picked a fight they'd just drag you away". ==Kim Jong-il== [[File:Kim Jong-il painting.jpg|thumb|Kim Jong-il visiting [[Mount Paektu]], his alleged birthplace]] In keeping with the modern mythologies that pervade North Korea's version of history, which is seen as crucial to the cult of personality and political control,{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052970203686204577114193593219330 |title=Pyongyang Myth-Builders Step It Up |author1=Jaeyeon Woo |author2=Alastair Gale |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=December 23, 2011 |accessdate=February 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222100522/http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052970203686204577114193593219330 |archivedate=February 22, 2014 }} it is alleged that Kim Jong-il was born on [[Mount Paektu]] at his father's secret base in 1942 (his actual birth was in 1941 in the [[Soviet Union]]) and that his birth was heralded by a swallow, caused winter to change to spring, a star to illuminate the sky, and a double rainbow spontaneously appeared.{{cite book |last=Becker |first=Jasper |authorlink=Jasper Becker |title=Rogue Regime : Kim Jong Il and the Looming Threat of North Korea |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UpZWfYqiVLMC&pg=PA91 |accessdate=December 19, 2014 |year=2005 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location= |isbn=9780198038108 |page=91}} These claims, like those surrounding his father, are apocryphal and continued throughout his life.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=284}} Starting in the early 1970s Kim Il-sung began to contemplate the succession question, albeit surreptitiously at first, but by 1975 Kim Jong-il was referred to as the "party center", or in connection with his father with references to "our great ''suryong'' (supreme leader) and the party center". In 1977, the first confirmation of Kim Jong-il's succession by name was published in a booklet which designated the younger Kim as the only heir to Kim Il-sung, that he was a loyal servant of his father and had inherited his father's virtues, and that all party members were to pledge their loyalty to Kim Jong-il. They were also urged to support his absolute authority and to obey him unconditionally.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|pp=276–280}} Prior to 1996, Kim Jong-il forbade the erection of statues of himself and discouraged portraits.{{harvnb|Demick|2009|p=123}} However, in 1996, schools were required to build a separate room for lectures dealing specifically with Kim Jong-il known as the Kim Jong-il Research Institute. They include a model of his birthplace. There are approximately 40,000 "research institutes" (total includes both Kim Il-Sung's and Kim Jong-il's) throughout the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0103/p01s04-woap.html |title=N. Korea escalates 'cult of Kim' to counter West's influence |author=Robert Marquand |publisher=The Christian Science Monitor |date=January 3, 2007 |accessdate=May 24, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108090310/http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0103/p01s04-woap.html |archivedate=January 8, 2012 }} Between 1973 and 2012, Jong-il accumulated no fewer than [[List of Kim Jong-il's titles|54 titles]], most of which had little to do or nothing at all with real political or military accomplishments since he never had any military training.{{cite book |last = 전 |first = 영선 |title = 다시 고쳐 쓴 북한의 사회와 문화 |trans-title=A New View of North Korean Society and Culture |publisher = 역락 |year = 2006 |isbn = 89-5556-491-0}} Over the course of his life, the government issued numerous propaganda reports of the great accomplishments achieved by Kim Jong-il, such as that he could walk and talk before the age of six months. The North Korean newspaper, ''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'', reported that an "unidentified French fashion expert" said of Kim's fashion, "Kim Jong-il mode, which is now spreading expeditiously worldwide, is something unprecedented in the world's history";{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100407-nkorea-leader-sets-world-fashion-trend-pyongyang |title=N.Korea leader sets world fashion trend: Pyongyang |publisher=''FRANCE 24'' |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=19 December 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219011527/http://www.france24.com/en/20100407-nkorea-leader-sets-world-fashion-trend-pyongyang |archivedate=19 December 2011 }} and that he could control the weather based on his mood.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8292848/The-Incredible-Kim-Jong-il-and-his-Amazing-Achievements.html |title=The Incredible Kim Jong-il |author=Julian Ryall |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |date=January 31, 2011 |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418170850/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8292848/The-Incredible-Kim-Jong-il-and-his-Amazing-Achievements.html |archivedate=April 18, 2012 }} The Korean Central News Agency has also reported, among other things, that according to eye witness accounts "nature and the sky unfolded such mysterious ecstasy in celebration of the birthday of Kim Jong Il."{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2009/200902/news12/20090212-13ee.html |title=Unprecedented Natural Phenomena on Jong Il Peak |publisher=KCNA |date=February 12, 2009 |accessdate=February 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012053910/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2009/200902/news12/20090212-13ee.html |archivedate=October 12, 2014 }} To commemorate Kim Jong-il's 46th birthday, [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[botanist]] [[Kamo Mototeru]] cultivated a new [[perennial]] [[begonia]] named "[[Kimjongilia]]" (literally, "flower of Kim Jong-il").{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/kimjongilia-the-flower-of-a-fallen-dictator/2011/12/20/gIQAeHjH7O_blog.html |title=Kimjongilia: the flower of a fallen dictator |author=Melissa Bell |publisher=Washington Post |date=December 20, 2011 |accessdate=June 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archivedate=January 29, 2012 }} ===After death=== [[File:Pyongyang Metro Tour (14928222244).jpg|thumb|''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'' carrying articles on Kim Jong-il's revolutionary exploits]] After his death on December 17, 2011, the [[Korean Central News Agency]] (KCNA) said that layers of ice ruptured with an unprecedentedly loud crack at Chon Lake on Mount Paektu and a snowstorm with strong winds hit the area.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8973430/Mother-nature-mourns-Kim-Jong-il-death.html |title=Mother nature mourns Kim Jong-il death |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |date=December 22, 2011 |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=no political paper by his son, Kim Jong-un, sought to solidify his father as the "Eternal General Secretary of our Party."{{cite web|url=http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/book/reading.php?12 |title=Let us brilliantly accomplish the revolutionary cause of Juche |author=Kim Jong-un |page=1 |publisher=''Naenara'' |year=2012 |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115032451/http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/book/reading.php?12 |archivedate=January 15, 2013 }} Many had been seen weeping during the 100-day mourning period, which is typical of [[Korean Confucianism|Korean Confucian]] society, and an analyst at [[South Korea]]'s [[Korea Institute for National Unification]] determined that much of the public grief evidenced during the mourning period was a genuine expression of sorrow.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/21/world/asia/north-korean-mourning-blends-emotion-and-coercion.html |title=North Korea’s Tears: A Blend of Cult, Culture and Coercion |author1=Choe Sang-hun |author2=Norimitsu Onishi |publisher=New York Times |date=December 20, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107084505/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/21/world/asia/north-korean-mourning-blends-emotion-and-coercion.html |archivedate=November 7, 2012 }} Yet, a journalist from [[Western culture|the West]] questioned the sincerity of the displays of grief.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16262027 |title=How genuine are the tears in North Korea? |author=Tom Geoghegan |publisher=BBC News |date=December 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821021248/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16262027 |archivedate=August 21, 2013 }} Similar to the mourning period of Kim Il-sung, individuals who did not follow the 100-day mourning period regulations{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9040152/North-Korea-threatens-to-punish-mobile-phone-users-as-war-criminals.html |title=North Korea threatens to punish mobile-phone users as 'war criminals' |author=Julian Ryall |publisher=The Telegraph |date=January 26, 2012 |accessdate=September 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825001639/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9040152/North-Korea-threatens-to-punish-mobile-phone-users-as-war-criminals.html |archivedate=August 25, 2013 }} or were thought to be insincere in their grief{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=8668 |title=Harsh Punishments for Poor Mourning |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824050537/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=8668 |archivedate=August 24, 2013 }} were subject to punishment and in some cases may have been executed.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/10/25/north-korean-official-executed-with-a-mortar_n_2015515.html |title=North Korean Official Executed With A Mortar Shell |publisher=Huffington Post UK |date=October 25, 2012 |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901020021/http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/10/25/north-korean-official-executed-with-a-mortar_n_2015515.html |archivedate=September 1, 2013 }} A notable example of this was the alleged death of [[Kim Chol]] and other high-ranking officials.{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/search1/2603000000.html?cid=AEN20121023010500315 |title=N. Korean leader dismissed, purged 31 ranking officials after appointment as heir: lawmaker |publisher=Yonhap News |date=October 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 29, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305023739/http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/search1/2603000000.html?cid=AEN20121023010500315 |archivedate=March 5, 2016 }} However, in the case of Chol, doubts have been raised as to the credibility of the original account with ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' stating that stories about violent deaths of North Korean elites tend to be "exaggerated" and observing the version of events disseminated by South Korean media was likely based on "gossip".{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/10/31/was_a_north_korean_general_really_executed_by_mortar_fire |title=Was a North Korean General Really Executed by Mortar Fire? |publisher=Foreign Policy |date=October 31, 2012 |accessdate=September 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901002000/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/10/31/was_a_north_korean_general_really_executed_by_mortar_fire |archivedate=September 1, 2013 }} Several large-scale bronze statues have been erected alongside statues of Kim Il-sung. They include a {{convert|5.7|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us|adj=on}} statue of Kim Jong-il and Kim Il-sung each riding a horse (the first large monument built after Kim Jong-il's death) and a {{convert|23|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us|adj=on}} tall statue at Mansudae, [[Pyongyang]].{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/08/25/2012082500347.html |title=Kim Jong-il replacing statues of Kim Il-sung with updated versions along with new statues of Kim Jong-il beside the ones of his father in each of the provincial capitals and other sites.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2015/07/27/in-north-korea-theres-a-new-growth-industry-statues-of-kim-jong-il/|title=In North Korea, there’s a new growth industry: Statues of Kim Jong Il|author=Anna Fifield|publisher=Washington Post|date=August 25, 2012|accessdate=July 29, 2015}} Following his death, numerous commemorative stamps and coins were made and slogans have }} ==Kim Jong-un== [[File:Mural with names of all 3 leaders (10170508054).jpg|thumb|An inscription with names of all three leaders]] [[Kim Jong-un]], the grandson of North Korea's founder, was largely absent from the public and government service until the mid-2000s. In 2010 he began being referred to as the "Young General" and by late 2011 as "Respected General". Like his father, he lacks any formal military training or service. With the death of his father, state media began to refer to him as the "Great Successor."{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/19/us-korea-north-idUSTRE7BI05B20111219 |title=North Korea mourns dead leader, son is Great Successor |author1=David Chance |author2=Jack Kim |publisher=''Reuters'' |date=December 19, 2011 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123152343/http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/19/us-korea-north-idUSTRE7BI05B20111219 |archivedate=January 23, 2013 }} Many also refer to him as “Supreme Leader”. When he was still a new ruler, the development of his own personality cult was well underway, with large numbers of posters, signs, and other propaganda being placed all over the country.{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/11/22/2012112200512.html |title=Slogan Hailing Kim Jong-un Carved into Hillside |publisher=''The Chosun Ilbo'' |date=November 22, 2012 |accessdate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102081235/http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/11/22/2012112200512.html |archivedate=January 2, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://world.time.com/2012/07/18/propaganda-campaign-grows-in-north-korea-as-kim-jong-un-consolidates-power/ |title=Propaganda Campaign Grows in North Korea as Kim Jong Un Consolidates Power |author=Austin Ramzy |publisher=Time Magazine |date=July 18, 2012 |accessdate=October 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022124037/http://world.time.com/2012/07/18/propaganda-campaign-grows-in-north-korea-as-kim-jong-un-consolidates-power/ |archivedate=October 22, 2013 }} A journalist from Japan's [[Asahi Shimbun]] said that his striking likeness in appearance to Kim Il-sung has helped solidify him as the undisputed ruler in the minds of the people.{{cite web |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/asia/korean_peninsula/AJ201201070045 |title=THROWBACK/ Shades of North Korea's founder in its young new leader |author=The Associated Press |publisher=''Asahi Shimbun'' |date=January 7, 2013 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017094909/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/asia/korean_peninsula/AJ201201070045 |archivedate=October 17, 2013 |df= }} Kim Jong-un marks the third generation of Kim family dynastic leadership. According to ''Daily NK'', people who criticized the succession were sent to re-education camps or otherwise punished and, after the mourning period of Kim Jong-il, government authorities began to increase their efforts on building the idolization of Kim Jong-un. After Kim Jong-il's death the [[Supreme People's Assembly#President|president of the Presidium]] announced that "Respected Comrade Kim Jong-un is our party, military and country’s supreme leader who inherits great comrade Kim Jong-il's ideology, leadership, character, virtues, grit and courage."{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/world/2011/December/Kim-Jong-Un-Named-NKorea-Supreme-Leader-/ |title=Kim Jong Un Named N. Korea 'Supreme Leader' |publisher=''CBN.com'' |date=December 29, 2011 |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309031235/http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/world/2011/December/Kim-Jong-Un-Named-NKorea-Supreme-Leader-/ |archivedate=March 9, 2014 }} Shortly after the new leader came to power, a {{convert|560|m|ft}}-long propaganda sign was erected in his honor near a lake in [[Ryanggang Province]]. The sign, supposedly visible from space, reads "Long Live General Kim Jong-un, the Shining Sun!"{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/11/23/half-kilometre-long-kim-jong-un-propaganda-message-visible-from-space/ |title=Half-kilometre long Kim Jong-un propaganda message visible from space
