|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411104013/http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/11/23/half-kilometre-long-kim-jong-un-propaganda-message-visible-from-space/ |archivedate=April 11, 2013 }} In 2013, the [[Workers' Party of Korea]] amended the ''[[Ten Principles for the Establishment of a Monolithic Ideological System]]'', which in practice serves as the primary legal authority and framework of the country,{{cite web |url=http://www2.law.columbia.edu/course_00S_L9436_001/North%20Korea%20materials/10%20principles%20of%20juche.html |title=Ten Principles for the Establishment of the One-Ideology System |publisher=[[Columbia Law School]] |accessdate=October 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516075420/http://www2.law.columbia.edu/course_00S_L9436_001/North%20Korea%20materials/10%20principles%20of%20juche.html |archivedate=May 16, 2013 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=10828 |title=NK Adds Kim Jong Il to 'Ten Principles' |author=Kang Mi Jin |publisher=Daily NK |date=August 9, 2013 |accessdate=October 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017061341/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=10828 |archivedate=October 17, 2013 }} to demand "absolute obedience" to Kim Jong-un.{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/10/10/2013101002043.html |title=N.Korean Regime Consolidating Personality Cult |publisher=The Chosun Ilbo |date=October 10, 2013 |accessdate=October 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012025537/http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/10/10/2013101002043.html |archivedate=October 12, 2013 }} Kim Jong-un's uncle, [[Jang Sung-taek]], was executed on December 12, 2013. His death was attributed, in part, to undermining the Kim family personality cult.{{cite web|url=http://38north.org/2013/12/amansourov121313/ |title=North Korea: What Jang’s Execution Means for the Future |author=Alexandre Mansourov |publisher=38 North |date=December 13, 2013 |accessdate=December 21, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219021309/http://38north.org/2013/12/amansourov121313/ |archivedate=December 19, 2013 }} His death has also been seen as a move by Kim Jong-un to consolidate his own cult.{{cite web|url=http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/what-jang-song-thaeks-purge-tells-us-about-kim-jong-uns-ambitions/ |title=What Jang Song-Thaek's Purge Tells Us About Kim Jong-Un's Ambitions |author=Ankit Panda |publisher=The Diplomat |date=December 13, 2013 |accessdate=December 21, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222232155/http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/what-jang-song-thaeks-purge-tells-us-about-kim-jong-uns-ambitions/ |archivedate=December 22, 2013 }} In 2015, at the end of the formal three-year mourning period for the death of Kim Jong-il, Kim Jong-un ordered the construction of new monuments to be built in every [[List of second-level administrative divisions of North Korea|county]] of North Korea. Extensive renovations to the Kumsusan Memorial Palace have also been ordered. According to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', analysts "say the order to erect more statues to the Kim family will be a heavy financial burden on an economy that is already struggling due to years of chronic mismanagement and international sanctions".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/11334556/Kim-Jong-un-orders-new-statues-to-strengthen-family-cult.html |title=Kim Jong-un orders new statues to strengthen family cult |author=Julian Ryall |publisher= |date=January 9, 2015 |accessdate=January 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121041859/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/11334556/Kim-Jong-un-orders-new-statues-to-strengthen-family-cult.html |archivedate=January 21, 2015 }} The first monument to be at least partially dedicated to Kim Jong-un was announced in January 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.nknews.org/2017/01/north-korea-to-erect-first-major-monument-to-kim-jong-un/ |title=North Korea to erect first major monument to Kim Jong Un |author=Hamish Macdonald |publisher=NK News |date=January 12, 2017 |accessdate=March 1, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302201124/https://www.nknews.org/2017/01/north-korea-to-erect-first-major-monument-to-kim-jong-un/ |archivedate=March 2, 2017 }} It is to be constructed on Mt. Paektu and also includes monuments dedicated to Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il. Additionally, stand alone "mosaic murals" of Kim Jong-un are being planned for major cities in each province.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=14337 |title=North Korean regime in search of suitable site for Kim Jong Un's mosaic mural |author=Kim Chae Hwan |publisher=DailyNK |date=January 26, 2017 |accessdate=March 1, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302114120/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=14337 |archivedate=March 2, 2017 }} ==Others== The personality cult extends to other members of the Kim family, although to a lesser degree. ===Kim Ung-u=== According to the official North Korean history, Kim Ung-u, Kim Il-sung’s paternal great-grandfather, fought against the American [[schooner]] USS ''General Sherman'' in the [[General Sherman incident|1866 incident]] and was also an anti-Japanese activist. However, these claims remain unsubstantiated and many historians outside of North Korea doubt their legitimacy.Suh, D.-S. (1988). ''Kim Il Sung: The North Korean Leader.'' New York: Columbia University Press. ===Kang Pan-sok=== [[Kang Pan-sok]] was the first member of the Kim family to have a cult of personality of her own to supplement that of her son, from the late 1960s onwards.{{cite book|author=Jae-Cheon Lim|title=Leader Symbols and Personality Cult in North Korea: The Leader State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yswqBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA24|date=24 March 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-56741-7|pages=24–25}} In addition to a museum and statue in Chilgol, her birthplace, she has been given the title "Mother of Korea" and has had songs and articles written in praise of her.{{rp|40}} ===Kim Hyong-jik=== [[Kim Hyong-jik]], the father of Kim Il-sung, is venerated by official North Korean historiographies for having been a prominent leader of the anti-colonial [[Korean independence movement]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uk-songun.com/index.php?p=1_112_KIM-IL-SUNG-CONDENSED-BIOGRAPHY |title=Kim Il-sung Condensed Biography |publisher=Association for the Study of Songun Politics UK |accessdate=June 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620204951/http://www.uk-songun.com/index.php?p=1_112_KIM-IL-SUNG-CONDENSED-BIOGRAPHY |archivedate=June 20, 2012 }}{{harvnb|Martin|2004|p=18}} In fact, official sources claim that Kim not only led the [[March 1st Movement|March 1st Uprising of 1919]], but also that it took place in Pyongyang—both blatant fabrications. While in reality Kim was at one point briefly detained for anti-Japanese activities,Lankov, A. N. "North Korea in 1945-8." ''From Stalin to Kim Il Sung: The Formation of North Korea, 1945-1960''. New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers UP, 2002. 1-48. Print. most outside scholars do not support claims of anything further.{{cite book |last=Martin |first=Bradley |title=Under the Loving Care of the Fatherly Leader |url= |accessdate= |year=2004 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |location=United States of America |isbn=0-312-32322-0 |page=18}}{{rp|727}} In fact, according to biographer Dae-Sook Suh, efforts to describe Kim Hyong-jik as playing a major role in the anti-Japanese struggle "seem to be directed more toward upgrading the attributes of Kim [Il-sung] as a pious son."{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=5}} This attribution became important as Kim Il-sung used these stories to aid his ascent to power. Kim Hyong-jik currently has a museum and statue dedicated to him in his hometown of Bonghwari. ===Kim Hyong-gwon=== [[Kim Hyong-gwon]], paternal uncle of Kim Il-Sung and brother of Kim Hyong-jik, is honored in North Korea as an anti-Japanese activist because he skirmished with local police, for which he was arrested and later died on January 12, 1936 during internment in Seoul. There is a statue in his honor in Hongwon, the site of the skirmish. ===Kim Jong-suk=== [[File:Kim Jong-il in North Korean propaganda (6075332268).jpg|thumb|Kim Jong-suk, the mother of Kim Jong-il embracing him]] [[Kim Jong-suk]] (Kim Jong-il's mother) is described as "a revolutionary immortal" and "an anti-Japanese war hero [who] upheld the original idea and policy of Kim Il Sung and performed distinguished feats in the development of the movement for the women's emancipation in Korea."{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201203/news08/20120308-09ee.html |title=National Meeting on International Women's Day Held |publisher=KCNA |date=March 8, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219162257/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201203/news08/20120308-09ee.html |archivedate=February 19, 2014 }} She is typified as a model revolutionary, wife, and maternal figure, and North Korean society looks to stories of her as examples of how to live life.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01300&num=67 |title=Unrevealed Story of Kim Jong Suk, Mother of Kim Jong Il |author=Choi Jin I |publisher=Daily NK |date=February 25, 2005 |accessdate=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923222831/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01300&num=67 |archivedate=September 23, 2015 }} Although she was first lady of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea in the first year of its founding in 1948, she died in 1949, and starting in 1974, in conjunction with her son Kim Jong-il's rise to position as the heir apparent, she was increasingly praised and her accomplishments memorialized throughout the nation. A museum and statue was built in her home town in her honor and she was called an "indomitable Communist revolutionary" by [[Kim Sung-ae]] who was Kim Il-sung's then present wife, despite being largely ignored until this point.{{harvnb|Suh|1988|p=279}} Thus, originally she was honored as a guerrilla, but not necessarily as a mother or wife. In the 1990s, Kim Jong-suk’s portrait was even added to those of Kim Il-Sung and Kim Jong-Il, which were displayed in every household and building and treated as sacred objects of veneration and worship. Furthermore, when referring to the "three Great Generals of [[Paektu Mountain|Paekdu Mountain]]," a sacred dormant volcano on North Korea's northern border with China, North Koreans understand this to mean Kim Il Sung, Kim Jong Suk, and their son Kim Jong Il. There is a wax replica of her in the [[International Friendship Exhibition]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201204/news26/20120426-27ee.html |title=Wax Replica of Kim Jong Suk Displayed |publisher=KCNA |date=April 26, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228125928/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201204/news26/20120426-27ee.html |archivedate=February 28, 2014 }} ==Familism in the personality cult== [[Familism]] is a type of [[collectivism]] in which the one is expected to prioritize the needs of the greater society or family over the needs of the individual. This plays out on a large scale in North Korea, where the Great Leader Kim Il-Sung is Father and the Worker's Party is Mother. Thus, not only are the people expected to cherish their birth parents and treat them with all the respect demanded of traditional Confucian filial piety, but they must cherish and adore the ruling Kim family and the Mother Party even more so. Familism in North Korea stems from a combination of the traditional East Asian Confucian value of [[filial piety]], the communist system of collectivism, and the Kim cult of personality. As a traditional East Asian and Confucian value, the importance of family has come to resonate through all aspects of North Korean life, from politics to the economy to education and even to interpersonal relationships between friends and enemies. When the Soviet Union first entered North Korea in 1945 to start its occupation, it had to start almost from scratch in establishing a communist base in the capital region of Pyongyang.Hwang, Kyung Moon. "Early North Korea." ''A History of Korea: An Episodic Narrative''. Houndmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire: Palgrave Macmillan, 2010. 213-24. Print. In fact, the Soviets' ideologies of communism and socialism were likely as foreign to the Koreans of Pyongyang as the Soviets themselves. However, by emphasizing family and a father-child relationship between the Soviet Union and Korea, and later between Kim Il-Sung and the North Korean people, Kim not only managed to apply Western Marxism to an Asian state, but also to secure his own personality cult, thereby constructing a sense of unquestioning loyalty toward him amongst the North Korean people when North Korea was at its most vulnerable to unwelcome western influences. However, in the late 1960s after the establishment of [[Juche]] as official North Korean ideology, through the cult of personality North Korea began to prominently focus the family ideology more on the North Korean nation itself, with Kim Il-Sung himself as the new ''[[pater familias]]''.{{cn|date=August 2017}} The cults of personality also promote the idea of the ruling Kims as a model family. In grief over the death of his second son, Kim Pyong-Il in 1947, Kim Il-Sung returned to the very same spot a decade later with a Korean shaman to perform rituals to "assuage his loss and pain."Cumings, B. (2004). ''North Korea: Another Country.'' New York: The New Press. There was particular stress on the Confucian filial love of the son for his parents. After their deaths Kim dedicated monuments to his father and mother, respectively. However, biographer Dae-Sook Suh doubts the sincerity of Kim’s displays of reverence of his parents. In considering Kim’s relatively independent childhood, Suh does not believe that Kim held any special love for his parents that would necessitate separate museums and statues for each. Instead, Suh says that "his purpose, rather, seems to be more self-serving: an effort to build his own image as a pious Korean son from a revolutionary family." By publicly portraying himself as a loyal son who loved his mother and father, Kim positioned himself to demand the same filial loyalty from his subjects. Likewise, in celebration of his father's 60th [[Day of the Sun|birthday]], Kim Jong-Il produced [[Korean revolutionary opera|three operas]] for him,{{cn|date=August 2017}} built three monuments, including North Korea's [[Arch of Triumph (Pyongyang)|Arch of Triumph]], for his 70th birthday in 1982,McCormack, Gavan, ''Target North Korea: Pushing North Korea to the Brink of Nuclear Catastrophe''. Nation Books, 2004. 59.'' and upon Kim Il-Sung’s death in 1994, Kim Jong-Il declared three years of mourning before fully claiming leadership of North Korea. ==Veneration for female family members and the mother party== Another factor that makes North Korea unique is its notable emphasis also on the maternal aspect of leadership.{{cn|date=August 2017}} In a political decision distinct from other socialist regimes, starting around the 1960s, North Korea gradually abandoned the idea of leadership as paternal—such as with Stalin in the Soviet Union or Mao in China—and increasingly referred to their leaders in maternal terms, despite the fact that nearly all of the leading family and party are, in fact, male.{{cn|date=August 2017}} ==Monuments, images and cost== [[File:Tower-Of-Eternal-Life-2014.jpg|thumb|right|200px|One of the many Towers of Eternal Life]] By 1992, there had been nearly 40,000 statues of Kim Il-sung erected throughout the country,{{cite book|last=Cha |first=Victor |title=The Impossible State: North Korea Past and Future |year=2013 |publisher=ECCO, Harper Collins |location=New York City, USA |isbn=978-0-06-199851-5 |page=73}} and with his death in 1994 the government began erecting 3,200 obelisks, called ''Towers of Eternal Life'', in every town and city.{{harvnb|Demick|2009|pp=99–100}} These obelisks espouse the virtues of the "Great Marshal" and, like the other monuments, citizens (and tourists) are required to present flowers and other tokens of respect to the statues during certain holidays and when they visit them.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8110093.stm |title=Satellites uncover North Korea |year=2011 |publisher=''BBC News'' |author=Adrian Brown |accessdate=2013-09-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903104811/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8110093.stm |archivedate=2013-09-03 }}{{cite book|last=Robert L |first=Worden |title=North Korea: A Country Study |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ybmFuqReAqUC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76 |year=2009 |publisher=Government Printing Office |location=United States of America |isbn=9780160814228 |page=76 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211192847/http://books.google.com/books?id=ybmFuqReAqUC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76 |archivedate=2013-12-11 }} There are legal requirements associated with photographing statues of the Kims including one that states visitors must photograph the entire statue, not just the head or any other individual part. After the death of Kim Jong-il the government began to inscribe his name on each of the obelisks and build new statues in his image. [[File:Mangyongdae Children's Palace 09.JPG|thumb|left|Portraits on the Mangyongdae Children's Palace]] [[File:North Korea-Pyongyang-Sunan International Airport-Staff's clothing-01.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il badges|Kim Il-sung lapel pin]]]] Images of Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il are prominent in places associated with public transportation, hanging at every North Korean train station and airport.{{cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Korea/NE03Dg01.html|title=Potent portraits in North Korea|date=May 3, 2012|publisher=''Asia Times Online''|author=Andrei Lankov|accessdate=2013-09-01}} Every North Korean household is required to have a [[Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il portraits|picture of both Kims]] hanging on a wall. Nothing else may hang on that wall and they are given special cloths to clean the images daily.{{harvnb|Demick|2009|p=316}} Party members in neighborhoods are assigned to inspect houses for dusty portraits. If dust is found, a fine has to be paid, its amount depending on the thickness of the layer. The portraits have to be hung high up, so that people in the room may not stand higher than them.{{Cite web|title=Portraits to inspire and intimidate: North Korea's omnipresent leaders |author=Oliver Hotham |work=The Guardian |date=4 September 2015 |accessdate=4 September 2015 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/04/north-korea-portraits-great-leaders |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905125848/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/04/north-korea-portraits-great-leaders |archivedate=5 September 2015 }} [[Worker's Party of Korea|Party]] cadres and military officials must keep three portraits, that of the two deceased leaders and one of Kim Il-sung's wife, Kim Jong-suk.{{cite book|last=Lanʹkov |first=Andreĭ N. |authorlink=Andrei Lankov |title=North of the DMZ: Essays on Daily Life in North Korea |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hmKiUkUE_p8C&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26 |year=2007 |publisher=McFarland and Company |location=United States of America |isbn=0-7864-2839-2 |pages=26–27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111115013/http://books.google.com/books?id=hmKiUkUE_p8C&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26 |archivedate=2014-01-11 }} The images are only allowed to be made by government approved artists at specific [[Mansudae Art Studio|Mansudae workshops]]. Images found within newspapers or other publications are to be respected and one must not throw away, deface or otherwise misuse a page that contains an image. They are to be collected and returned. Adult North Koreans are also required to wear a [[Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il badges|lapel pin that features their image]] on the left side, above their heart. There have been sporadic stories of people risking their lives to save the portraits from various disasters but few accounts have been verified.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/apr/28/northkorea |title=Train blast victims died saving leaders' portraits |author=Simon Jeffery |publisher=The Guardian |date=April 28, 2004 |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828012958/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/apr/28/northkorea |archivedate=August 28, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/23/world/la-fg-north-korea-heroes23-2010jan23 |title=North Korea honors seamen who tried to save Kim portraits |author=John M. Glionna |publisher=LA Times |date=January 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 21, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224124035/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/23/world/la-fg-north-korea-heroes23-2010jan23 |archivedate=December 24, 2013 }} In 2012, a 14-year-old girl drowned while trying to save the images from her family's home during a flash flood. The North Korean government posthumously bestowed upon her the "Kim Jong-Il Youth Honor Award" and her school will be renamed after her.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90777/7859315.html |title=DPRK honors schoolgirl who died saving Kim portraits |publisher=People's Daily Online |date=June 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105161958/http://english.people.com.cn/90777/7859315.html |archivedate=November 5, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/a-14-year-old-girl-died-trying-to-save-a-portrait-of-kim-jong-il-and-now-shes-being-called-a-hero-2012-6 |title=A 14-year-old girl died trying to save a portrait of Kim Jong Il and now she's being called a hero |author=Adam Taylor |date=June 27, 2012 |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426063404/http://www.businessinsider.com/a-14-year-old-girl-died-trying-to-save-a-portrait-of-kim-jong-il-and-now-shes-being-called-a-hero-2012-6 |archivedate=April 26, 2013 }} The [[Kumsusan Palace of the Sun]] was built as the official residence of Kim Il-sung in 1976. After his death it was converted into his [[mausoleum]] (and then that of his son's).{{harvnb|Burdick|2010|p=100}} It is reported to have cost between $100–900 million.{{harvnb|Hassig|2009|p=53}}{{harvnb|Kim|2001|p=20}} Kumsusan is the largest mausoleum dedicated to a Communist leader.{{cite web|url=http://m.ibtimes.co.uk/kim-jong-il-mausoleum-pyongyang-426801.html |title=Kim Jong-il’s Mausoleum, As Described By Its First Western Visitors |author=Mark Johanson |publisher=International Business Times |date=January 23, 2013 |accessdate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928041208/http://m.ibtimes.co.uk/kim-jong-il-mausoleum-pyongyang-426801.html |archivedate=September 28, 2013 }} The overall estimated cost of maintaining the personality cult varies greatly between published sources. A [[white paper]] by the [[Korea Institute for International Economic Policy]] placed the cost at 38.5% of North Korea's budget in 2004, up from 19% in 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Pyongyang:-budget-to-deify-Kim-Jong-il-increasing-8192.html |title=Pyongyang: budget to deify Kim Jong-il increasing |publisher=[[AsiaNews]] C.F. |date=January 10, 2007 |accessdate=October 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016063449/http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Pyongyang%3A-budget-to-deify-Kim-Jong-il-increasing-8192.html |archivedate=October 16, 2013 }} However, other sources such as South Korea's ''[[Chosun Ilbo]]'' and the [[United Kingdom]]'s ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' estimate the cost in 2012 at between $40 million and $100 million respectively.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9723048/Kim-Jong-il-personality-cult-costs-North-Korea-62m.html |title=Kim Jong-il personality cult costs North Korea £62m |author=Mike Firn |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=December 5, 2012 |accessdate=October 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104205536/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9723048/Kim-Jong-il-personality-cult-costs-North-Korea-62m.html |archivedate=November 4, 2013 }} Large scale construction projects for the Kim family has been blamed for the country's [[Economic stagnation|economic downturn]] in the 1980s.{{harvnb|Martin|2006|p=322-223}} ==Holidays== |date=December 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 28, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228072224/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?num=11312&cataId=nk01700 web|url=http://newfocusintl.com/chosun-north-korea-history/?fb_source=pubv1 |title=Chosun: North Korea’s Love-Hate Relationship with History |publisher="New Focus International" |date=May 31, 2013 tradition.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/dec/17/north-korea-homage-kim-dynasty ''North Korea pays homage to the Kim dynasty, past, present (and future?).''] Justin McCurry. The Guardian. London. 17 December 2012. Accessed 18 August 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-great-leader-rules-from-beyond-the-grave-1245349.html |title=The Great Leader rules from beyond the grave |last=Vines |first=Stephen |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=August 14, 1997 |accessdate=August 25, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122054400/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-great-leader-rules-from-beyond-the-grave-1245349.html |archivedate=January 22, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/910385/inside-north-korea-cult-of-the-kim-family |title=Inside North Korea: Cult Of The Kim Family |author=Holly Williams |publisher=[[BSkyB|Sky News]] |date=December 19, 2011 |accessdate=August 25, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224084530/http://news.sky.com/story/910385/inside-north-korea-cult-of-the-kim-family |archivedate=December 24, 2013 }} Former dictator of the [[Socialist Republic of Romania]], [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]], modeled his own [[Nicolae Ceaușescu's cult of personality|cult of personality]] partly on Kim Il-sung's personality cult. When he visited North Korea in 1971, he was impressed by the highly personal way that Kim ruled North Korea, launching the [[July Theses]] when he returned to [[Bucharest]].{{cite book|last=Sebetsyen|first=Victor|title=Revolution 1989: The Fall of the Soviet Empire|publisher=[[Pantheon Books]]|location=New York City|year=2009|isbn=0-375-42532-2}} ==Historical significance== Over the past half-century, the North Korean system has promoted an image of not only Kim Il-sung, but also his family, as a nationalist cult.{{cn|date=August 2017}} (see [[North Korean cult of personality#Others|Other]]) Thus, Kim Il-sung staked his claim as uniquely deserving and qualified to the exclusion of all other potential claimants to leadership by promoting the myth of an impressive family lineage. Kim Il-sung was not only descended and born of revolutionary leaders, but he married a revolutionary leader ([[Kim Jong-suk]]) and fathered a revolutionary leader ([[Kim Jong-il]]).{{cn|date=August 2017}} This in turn would help justify the succession of Kim Jong-il and then Kim Jong-un in replacing their fathers. The idea is that as long as his bloodline continues to rule, Kim Il-sung’s righteous and godlike spirit lives on in the North Korean leadership.{{cn|date=August 2017}} {{for|the Elizabeth Moon novel|The Deed of Paksenarrion}} {{italic title}} [[File:Fealtycover.jpg|thumb|Cover of the first edition, published by [[Phantasia Press]]. Art by [[Paul Lehr]].]] '''''Oath of Fealty''''' is a 1981 novel by American writer [[Larry Niven]] and [[Jerry Pournelle]], published originally by [[Phantasia Press]], then by [[Timescape Books]], with numerous reprints. Set in the near future, it involves an [[arcology]], a large inhabited structure, called Todos Santos, which rises above a crime-ridden [[Los Angeles, California]], but has little beyond casual contact with the city. The novel popularized the phrase "think of it as evolution in action," which occurs elsewhere in Niven's books. The novel anticipated the building of the [[Los Angeles County Metro Rail|Los Angeles Subway]]. It was included in [[David Pringle]]'s book ''[[Science Fiction: The 100 Best Novels]]''.
==Plot summary== In the near future, a race riot results in the destruction of an area just outside Los Angeles. The city sells the construction rights to a private company, which then constructs an arcology, named Todos Santos. The higher standard of living enjoyed by Todos Santos residents causes resentment among Angelenos. The arcology dwellers have evolved a different culture, sacrificing privacy - there are cameras (not routinely monitored) even in the private apartments - in exchange for security. The residents are fiercely loyal to the arcology and its management, and the loyalty runs both ways. During the course of the novel, Todos Santos is compared to a [[feudal society]], with loyalty and obligations running both ways, hence the title of the novel. The systems at the arcology are run by MILLIE, an advanced computer system, and some high-level executives have direct links to MILLIE via bio-electronic [[Brain-computer interface|implants]] in their brains.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pringle|first1=David|title=Science Fiction: The 100 Best Novels|isbn=0-947761-11-X|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=8m_EAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT200&lpg=PT200&dq=MILLIE+oath+of+fealty|accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> Other workers in the arcology work by [[telepresence]], including one woman who remotely operates construction equipment on a [[Colonization of the Moon|lunar base]].
Todos Santos causes resentment among Angelenos, but has improved their lives as well. The company that owns the arcology tows icebergs in, solving the water shortage for all Southern Californians. Todos Santos has dug a Los Angeles subway using a digging machine, which uses an [[oxyhydrogen]] torch. Todos Santos is at the hub of the subway system, and contains a huge mall, which Angelenos may visit. This easy access causes Los Angeles' city officials to complain about the shopping dollars and tax revenues going outside the city limits.
As the story opens, three young Angelenos sneak into the maintenance areas of Todos Santos. When they are detected by Todos Santos' security systems and personnel, they give every appearance of being terrorists, including spoofing the correct electronic access codes. When non-lethal means of stopping the three fail, Deputy Manager Preston Sanders orders lethal gas released rather than risk a bomb going off. Two of the intruders are killed. They turn out to be youths, with high tech equipment and boxes with such labels as "bomb", but without the actual means of harming the arcology. It soon turns out that they were duped by the "Friends of Man and the Earth" (FROMATE), anti-technology zealots who want to see Todos Santos destroyed or abandoned, as a means of forcing the arcology to turn off its lethal defenses for a later real attack.
The deaths of the two youths cause political problems. Sanders is charged with murder. While arcology manager Art Bonner is quite prepared to defy the city authorities, Sanders turns himself in. The arcology is forced to turn off its lethal defenses as the FROMATEs planned. When that happens, they soon face a full-fledged attack by the FROMATEs, which they deter by non-lethal means, until the intruders prove they have deadly weapons, at which point Todos Santos security responds in kind, shooting and killing most of the intruders. While city authorities are still reacting to this, the arcology launches a jailbreak, the idea of chief engineer (and resident genius) Tony Rand. They tunnel under the jail using the tunneling machine that the "Saints" used to build the L.A. subway, release sleep gas into the jail, and free Sanders.
Los Angeles soon retaliates with arrest and search warrants, but they are soon defeated by the sheer size of the arcology and the ability of the Todos Santos executives, aided in part by their direct links to MILLIE, to hide Rand and Sanders. After Todos Santos shows that it can cause Los Angeles trouble, such as by contaminating the Los Angeles water supply with salt water, and by work stoppages among the telepresence operators, a truce is arrived at: Rand and Sanders will leave the country permanently, and relations between Los Angeles and Todos Santos will be restored. In effect, Todos Santos has won, if only by restoring the ''[[status quo|status quo ante]].''
Notable Quote: "Think of it as Evolution in Action" (Tony Rand)
==Reception== It was chosen as one of the [[Science Fiction: The 100 Best Novels|100 best science fiction novels from 1949-1984]], by critic [[David Pringle]]. It has been nominated numerous times for a [[Prometheus Award]] for best classic libertarian science fiction novel.
== References == {{reflist}} * Larry Niven, Jerry Pournelle: ''Oath of Fealty.'' Baen Books, 2007. {{ISBN|1-4165-5516-1}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=BC1lxSwsZewC&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=%22oath+of+fealty%22+niven&source=bl&ots=HSwMOghdKm&sig=-e7B7Al_SKduLVZ83oDyw9u23XI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IBH2UfimBsTXigLa4YCoCg&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCDg8#v=onepage&q=%22oath%20of%20fealty%22%20niven&f=false review, from ''Science Fiction: A Very Short Introduction'', by David Seed, at Google Books]

{{short description|A distinct area of continental crust that existed as a major landmass in the geological past}} A '''paleocontinent''' or '''palaeocontinent''' is a distinct area of [[continental crust]] that existed as a major landmass in the geological past.<ref name="Nance" /> There have been many different landmasses throughout Earth’s time. They range in sizes, some are just a collection of small microcontinents while others are large conglomerates of crust. As time progresses and sea levels rise and fall more crust can be exposed making way for larger landmasses. The continents of the past shaped the evolution of organisms on Earth and contributed to the climate of the globe as well. As land masses break apart, species are separated and those that were once the same now have evolved to their new climate. The constant movement of these landmasses greatly determines the distribution of organisms on the Earth's surface. This is evident with how similar fossils are found on completely separate continents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/dynamic/continents.html|title=Rejoined continents [This Dynamic Earth, USGS]|website=pubs.usgs.gov|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> Also, as continents move, mountain building events (orogenies) occur, causing a shift in the global climate as new rock is exposed and then there is more exposed rock at higher elevations. This causes glacial ice expansion and an overall cooler global climate. Which effects the overall global climate trend of the Earth. The movement of the continents greatly affects the overall dispersal of organisms throughout the world and the trend in climate throughout the Earth’s history.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Caledonian-Orogenic-Belt|title=Caledonian orogenic belt {{!}} geological region, Europe|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-06-12|language=en}}</ref> Examples include [[Laurentia]], [[Baltica]] and [[Avalonia]], which collided together during the [[Caledonian orogeny]] to form the [[Old Red Sandstone]] paleocontinent of [[Laurussia]].<ref name="Nance">{{cite journal | url=http://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/18/12/pdf/i1052-5173-18-12-4.pdf | title=The Rheic Ocean: Origin, Evolution, and Significance | author=Nance R.D. | journal=GSA Today | volume=18 | issue=12 | pages=4–12 | doi=10.1130/GSATG24A.1 | year=2008}}</ref> Another example includes a collision that occurred during the late Pennsylvanian and early Permian time when there was a collision between the two continents of Tarimsky and Kirghiz-Kazakh. This collision was caused because of their askew convergence when the paleoceanic basin closed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Biske|first=Yu|date=August 1995|title=Late Paleozoic collision of the Tarimskiy and Kirghiz-Kazakh paleocontinents.|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yuriy_Biske/publication/285306591_Late_Paleozoic_collision_of_the_Tarimskiy_and_Kirghiz-Kazakh_paleocontinents/links/566ee88408ae4d4dc8f7d836.pdf|journal=Geotectonics|volume=29|pages=26}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
== Examples == The examples below are condensed in order to portray a brief overview of several paleocontinents.
=== Rodinia === [[File:Rodinia reconstruction.jpg|thumb|A reconstruction of the supercontinent Rodinia.]]
==== Location ==== [[Rodinia]] was centered on the equator and reached from 60° N to 60° S.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.earth.northwestern.edu/people/seth/Export/midcontinent/rodinia.pdf|title=The first supercontinent-1.1 billion years ago|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref>
==== Time period ==== 1.2-1 bya to 800-850 mya, [[Proterozoic Eon]] - end of [[Precambrian]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Z.X. Li, et al.|first=S.V. Bogdanova|date=11 June 2017|title=Assembly, configuration, and break-up history of Rodinia: A synthesis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301926807001635|journal=Precambrian Research|volume=160|pages=179–210|via=Elsevier Science Direct|doi=10.1016/j.precamres.2007.04.021|bibcode=2008PreR..160..179L}}</ref>
==== Formation ==== It was the first supercontinent to form on Earth, all the continental crust on Earth came together and formed one giant land mass. This land mass was surrounded by an even larger ocean, known as Mirovia. There were about four smaller continents that collided and came together to form Rodinia. This event is called the [[Grenville Orogeny]]. This caused there to be mountain building along the areas of were continents collided. This is because the continental crust is not very dense so neither continent would sink or sub duct. This causes the formation of [[Fold and thrust belt|Fold and Thrust belts]], similar to the Himalayas today.<ref name=":0" />
==== Demise ==== Rodinia lasted for 250 mya and then began to come apart between 850 and 800 mya. The continent began to break part at a single point but then fractured and ripped open in three different directions. Two of the three rifts that were created were successful and the third failed. The breaking up Rodinia caused the formation of Gondwana or Gondwanaland and Laurentia.<ref name=":0" /> Rodinia’s breakup created many shallow coastal shelves that were not there before. The shelves were nutrient rich and this is thought to have led to the diversification of vegetative and non-vegetative life on Earth. The shelves in particular were the area where animal life is said to have started. The name Rodinia also alludes to this, in Russian it means ‘to give birth’ and in this case that is to animal life here on Earth.<ref name=":1" />
==== Climate ==== The climate at the end of Rodinia’s existence was cold and it is thought that this was the start of the first snowball Earth period. Rodinia already had some glaciation but as it tore apart, less dense rock began to rise causing more land area to be at higher elevations which encouraged more ice to stick. However, the time of Rodinia was a time of inactivity in Earth’s atmosphere.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://earth.usc.edu/~stott/Catalina/Precambrian.html|title=Precambrian Climate-Earth's Early Environment|last=|first=|date=11 June 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref> Also the atmosphere had little oxygen because Rodinia’s land surface was too harsh of an environment for land plants to flourish, the atmosphere was devoid of Oxygen and the ozone layer was much less extensive which attributed to the harsh land environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/Tonian-Period|title=Tonian Period|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref>
===Gondwana===
[[File:Es-Laurasia-Gondwana.png|thumb|Gondwana: Triassic Period, 200 mya]]
==== Location ====
[[Gondwana]] was located in the southern hemisphere, with the land mass that makes up current day Antarctica closest to the South Pole. The continent reaches from just above the equator to the South Pole. Current day South America and Africa are closest to the equator with Northern Africa intersecting the equator.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://earthguide.ucsd.edu/eoc/teachers/t_tectonics/p_pangaea2.html|title=Earthguide: Online Classroom - Definition: Pangaea|website=earthguide.ucsd.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
==== Time period ==== 600-180 mya, Precambrian - Jurassic Period.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2004AM/finalprogram/abstract_78645.htm|title=LINKING SUBDUCTION INITIATION, ACCRETIONARY OROGENESIS AND SUPERCONTINENT ASSEMBLY|website=gsa.confex.com|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
==== Formation ==== Gondwana was made of present-day South America, Africa, Arabia, India, Antarctica, Australia, and Madagascar. The Continent was fully formed by the late Precambrian period. This was 600 million years ago. It was an amalgamation of all the current southern hemisphere continents. Gondwana lasted through many different time periods and was a part of other super continents, like Pangea.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Gondwana-supercontinent|title=Gondwana {{!}} supercontinent|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-06-12|language=en}}</ref>
==== Demise ==== Gondwana broke up in distinct stages. The continent started to split during the [[Jurassic Period]] around 180 million years ago. The first event was the separation of the western half of Gondwana, which includes Africa and South America, from the eastern half, which includes Antarctica, Australia, Madagascar, and India. Next, 40 million years later, South America and Africa began to split which began to open up the Atlantic Ocean. Also around this time India and Madagascar began to detach from Australia and Antarctica, this separation created the Indian Ocean. Lastly in the Cretaceous India and Madagascar began to split and Australia and Antarctica began to detach from one another.<ref name=":2" />
==== Life ==== The life on Gondwana has changed throughout its existence. Gondwana was a smaller piece of Rodinina and stayed together all the way through the breakup of Pangea. This allowed Gondwana to host almost all species that have ever lived on Earth. Gondwana also was a part of some great mass extinction events. During the [[Ordovician]], sea levels rose so much that the entire Gondwana continent was covered, at this time marine life was dominant.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/ordovician/ordolife.html|title=Life of the Ordovician|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/cambrian/cambrian.php|title=The Cambrian Period|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> Also, vertebrates started to make an appearance in the fossil record. Terrestrial species started to become more prominent in the Silurian, however, in the [[Devonian]] modern fish and shark species began to diversify, and terrestrial vegetation begun colonizing the continent, as organic soil accumulation can be detected.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/devonian/devlife.html|title=Life of the Devonian|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/silurian/silurian.php|title=The Silurian Period|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> Amniotic eggs started to evolve as more terrestrial land became available with rising land masses and lowering sea levels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/mesozoic/cretaceous/cretlife.html|title=Life of the Cretaceous|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> During the Permian extinction, almost all marine species were lost, along with some terrestrial species. This event gave rise to terrestrial species, such as reptiles, dinosaurs, and small mammals.<ref name=":6" />
==== Climate ==== Gondwana experienced a variety of climates as it has been a land mass from 600 million years ago in the Precambrian to the Early Jurassic with the breakup of Pangea. In the [[Cambrian]], there was a warmer and milder climate because most continental crust was closer to the equator and not the poles.<ref name=":4" /> The continent endured an ice age during the Ordovician period and deglaciation was still occurring during the [[Silurian]] period.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":3" /> The climate started to become more humid and tropical throughout the globe and there was a lack of seasonality. The climate began to change again during the [[Mesozoic]], this time period was dominated by a very large and lengthy monsoon season, because of Pangea. Once Pangea began to break apart the climate started to cool, but Gondwana was already being broken apart.<ref name=":7" />
===Laurentia=== [[File:North america craton nps.gif|thumb|Laurentia, in its current context.]]
==== Location ==== The location of [[Laurentia]] has changed throughout time. In the late Proterozoic Laurentia could be found surrounded by Siberia, South Africa, Australia-Antarctica, and Amazonia-Baltica.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=F. Hoffman|first=Paul|date=12 June 2017|title=Did the breakout of Laurentia turn Gonwanaland inside out?|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/213564802?pq-origsite=gscholar|journal=Science|volume=252|pages=1409–1412|via=|doi=10.1126/science.252.5011.1409|bibcode=1991Sci...252.1409H}}</ref> Laurentia during the time of super contient Gondwana was smushed in between Eastern and Western Gondwana, but when Gondwana attached to Laurussia to form Pangea, laurentia was moved and was closer to northern Africa.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dalziel|first=Ian W. D.|last2=Salda|first2=Luis H. Dalla|last3=Gahagan|first3=Lisa M.|date=1994-02-01|title=Paleozoic Laurentia-Gondwana interaction and the origin of the Appalachian-Andean mountain system|url=http://gsabulletin.gsapubs.org/content/106/2/243|journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin|language=en|volume=106|issue=2|pages=243–252|doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1994)106<0243:plgiat>2.3.co;2|issn=0016-7606}}</ref>
==== Time period ==== 4 bya-present day, Precambrian-Quaternary.
==== Formation ==== Laurentia is the North American craton. It is one of the largest and oldest cratons dating back to Precambrian times. The craton itself includes the Canadian and Greenland shields, as well as the interior basin of North America, and the craton can also include the Cordilleran foreland of the Southwestern United States. The [[craton]] itself formed in deep time, the early Proterozoic age of the Earth and has stayed coherent since. It formed through many different [[orogeny]]’s and the suture zones that they create. These smaller land masses were made of Archean age crust and belts of Early Proterozoic island arcs. Laurentia has been a part of many supercontinents throughout its time. The formation of Laurentia is similar to the formation of Eurasia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hoffman|first=P. F.|date=1988|title=United Plates of America, The Birth of a Craton: Early Proterozoic Assembly and Growth of Laurentia|url=https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.ea.16.050188.002551|journal=Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences|volume=16|issue=1|pages=543–603|doi=10.1146/annurev.ea.16.050188.002551|bibcode=1988AREPS..16..543H}}</ref>
==== Demise ==== Laurentia is presently still coherent and still a continental craton, now it goes by the name North America. The craton can be found stretching from Alberta, Canada to the Eastern coast of both Canada and the United States. The craton stretches from the south eastern United States to Greenland. The western border of Laurentia can be found on the eastern side of the Rocky Mountains.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/North_america_craton_nps.gif/300px-North_america_craton_nps.gif|title=North American Craton|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 June 2017}}</ref>
==== Life ==== Sea level rose in the [[Cambrian]] period which gave rise to marine invertebrates which flourished with the rise in sea level.<ref name=":4" /> Life in the Ordovician continued to be dominated by marine animals and vegetation. Also, vertebrates started to make up a portion of the animals on Earth. However sponges and algae were still the most dominant species type. Marine animals were the most dominant but terrestrial species started to appear at the end of the Ordovician.<ref name=":3" /> Life in the Silurian was still dominated by marine species but terrestrial species are much more prominent than they had been previously.<ref name=":5" /> When Laurentia moved into the Devonian period fish began to diversify and life had begun colonizing land as this is when organic soil accumulation can be detected. More modern fish began to develop as time went on, with the addition of shark diversification. Also, amniotic eggs started to evolve as more terrestrial land became available with rising land masses.<ref name=":9" /> The next event was the Permian extinction where almost all species in the oceans died off along with many terrestrial species. This then gave rise to terrestrial animals, such as reptiles, dinosaurs, and small mammals.<ref name=":6" /> At the end of this new era was a mass extinction of Dinosaurs and reptiles, this led mammals to flourish as they could take over many of the niches that became vacant.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/mesozoic/cretaceous/cretaceous.php|title=The Cretaceous Period|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
==== Climate ==== Laurentia experienced a variety of climates as it has been a land mass for billions of years. The craton experienced an ice age during the late Proterozoic and another during the Ordivician period. During the Cambrian, there was no ice age and it was slightly warmer as most continents avoided the poles giving land at this time a milder climate.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":4" /> Deglaciation was still occurring during the Silurian period after the ice age of the Ordovician.<ref name=":5" /> The climate started to move to become more humid and tropical throughout the Earth. There weren’t many seasons. The climate began to change when Laurentia entered the Mesozoic Era, this time period was dominated by a very large and lengthy monsoon season, because of Pangea.<ref name=":7" /> At the end of the Cretaceous, seasons started to return and the Earth entered another ice age type event.<ref name=":10" />
===Pangea=== [[File:Pangea continents and oceans.svg|thumb|Pangea]]
==== Location ==== The continent spanned from 85° N to 90° S. [[Pangea]] was centered over the equator, and encompassed area from the North to the South poles. The Southeastern part of present-day North America and the Northern region of current day Africa intersected the equator. Present-day Eastern Asia was furthest North and Antarctica and Australia were furthest South.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/pangaea-present-lesson-2|title=Pangaea to the Present Lesson #2 {{!}} Volcano World {{!}} Oregon State University|website=volcano.oregonstate.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
==== Time period ==== 299–272 mya to 200 mya, Early Permian-Early Jurassic.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Pangea|title=Pangea {{!}} supercontinent|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-06-12|language=en}}</ref>
==== Formation ==== Pangea was created by the continent of Gondwanaland and the continent of Laurussia. During the Carboniferous period the two continents came together to form the supercontinent of Pangea. The mountain building events that happened at this time created the Appalachian Mountains and the Variscan Belt of Central Europe. However, not all landmasses on Earth had attached themselves onto Pangea. It took until the late Permian until the Siberian land mass collided with Pangea.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Torsvik|first=T. H.|last2=van der Voo|first2=R.|last3=Cocks|first3=L. R. M.|date=2003-04-01|title=Formation of Pangea|pages=2179|bibcode=2003EAEJA.....2179T}}</ref> The only land mass to not be a part of Pangea were the former North and South China plates, they created a much smaller land mass in the ocean. There was a massive ocean that encompassed the world called Panthalassa, because most of the continental crust was sutured together into one giant continent there was a giant ocean to match.
==== Demise ==== Pangea broke apart after 70 million years. The supercontinent was torn apart through fragmentation, which is where parts of the main landmass would break off in stages. There were two main events that led to the dispersal of Pangea. The first was a passive rifting event that occurred in the Triassic period. This rifting event caused the Atlantic Ocean to form. The other event was an active rifting event. This happened in the Lower Jurassic and caused the opening of the Indian Ocean.This breakup took 17 million years to complete.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frizon de Lamotte|first=Dominique|last2=Fourdan|first2=Brendan|last3=Leleu|first3=Sophie|last4=Leparmentier|first4=François|last5=de Clarens|first5=Philippe|date=2015-05-01|title=Style of rifting and the stages of Pangea breakup|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014TC003760/abstract|journal=Tectonics|language=en|volume=34|issue=5|pages=2014TC003760|doi=10.1002/2014TC003760|issn=1944-9194|bibcode=2015Tecto..34.1009F}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bortolotti|first=Valerio|last2=Principi|first2=Gianfranco|date=2005-12-01|title=Tethyan ophiolites and Pangea break-up|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1440-1738.2005.00478.x/abstract|journal=Island Arc|language=en|volume=14|issue=4|pages=442–470|doi=10.1111/j.1440-1738.2005.00478.x|issn=1440-1738}}</ref>
==== Life ==== Pangea formed roughly 20 million years before the Permian Extinction. During the Permian Extinction over 95% of all marine species were lost and 70% of terrestrial species were lost.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/Permian-extinction|title=Permian Extinction|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref> The Triassic period of Pangea became a time of recovery from the Permian Extinction. This recovery included the rise of sea levels which created extensive shallow oceanic shelves for large marine reptiles. This recovery period was when terrestrial animals flourished and when land reptiles diversified and flourished, along with the appearance of Dinosaurs. These Dinosaurs would become what characterizes the life forms of the following periods, the Jurassic and Cretaceous. Lastly at the end of the Triassic and the beginning of the Jurassic was the first appearance of small shrew like mammals that came from reptiles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/Triassic-Period|title=Triassic Period|last=|first=|date=11 June 2017|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref>
====Climate==== The main characteristic of Pangea’s climate is that its position on Earth was advantageous for starting a cycle of megamonsoonal circulation. The monsoons reached their maximum strength in the Triassic period of the Mesozoic. During the late Carboniferous, there was peat formation in what is currently Europe and the Eastern areas of North America. The wetter, swamp like conditions needed to form peat were contrasted with the dry conditions on the Colorado Plateau. Nearing the end of the Carboniferous the region of Pangea centered on the equator became drier. In the Permian, this dryness was contrasted with seasonal rainfall, and this type of climate became more normal and widespread on the continent. However, during the Triassic, the Colorado Plateau started to regain some moisture and there was a shift in wind direction. Around the same time parts of current day Australia that were found at higher latitudes were much drier and seasonal in character. At the start of the Jurassic the megamonsoon started to fall apart as drying started to happen to Gondwana and the southern portion of Laurasia.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=T Parrish|first=Judith|date=11 June 2017|title=Climate of the Supercontinent Pangea|jstor=30081148|journal=The Journal of Geology|volume=101|pages=215–233|via=|doi=10.1086/648217|bibcode=1993JG....101..215P}}</ref>
